Visitors who use the AddThis service to share content do not need to register or provide any personal information. The AddThis service providers collect non-personal data, including the aggregate and summary statistics on browsers and usage patterns. AddThis also uses non-personal data to manage the service efficiently and diagnose server problems. Although AddThis offers some analytics and usage data to CDC, these reports do not include any personally identifiable information. The reports are password protected and only available to members of CDC and other designated staff requiring this information to perform their duties. \xa0The AddThis Privacy policy is available at: http://www.addthis.com/privacyexternal icon\nExit Notification/Disclaimer Policy\nLinks with this icon (external icon) indicate that you are leaving a CDC Web site.\nThe link may lead to a non-federal site, but it provides additional information that is consistent with the intended purpose of a federal site.\nThe Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) cannot attest to the accuracy of a non-federal site.\nLinking to a non-federal site does not constitute an endorsement by HHS or any of its employees of the sponsors or the information and products presented on the site.\nYou will be subject to the destination site’s privacy policy when you follow the link. For more information on exit notifications and disclaimers for non-federal Web sites, the following resources may be helpful:\nHHS Web standardsexternal icon\nWebcontent.govexternal icon\nEndorsement Disclaimer — Pop-Up Advertisements\nWhen visiting our Web site, your Web browser may produce pop-up advertisements. These advertisements were most likely produced by other Web sites you visited or by third party software installed on your computer. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not endorse or recommend products of services for which you may view a pop-up advertisement on your computer screen while visiting our site.\nImage Disclaimer\nMany of the images used on this website are licensed stock photography images that feature model(s). The models have no affiliation with The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the images are for illustrative purposes only.\nInformation Disclaimer\nThe information provided using this Web site is only intended to be general summary information to the public. It is not intended to take the place of either the written law or regulations.\nIntrusion Detection\nThis site is maintained by the U.S. Government. It is protected by various provisions of Title 18, U.S. Code. Violations of Title 18 are subject to criminal prosecution in federal court.\nFor site security purposes and to ensure that this service remains available to all users, we employ software programs to monitor traffic to identify unauthorized attempts to upload or change information, or otherwise cause damage. In the event of authorized law enforcement investigations, and pursuant to any required legal process, information from these sources may be used to help identify an individual.\nCDC iTunes Disclaimer\nLimitation of Liability. The materials embodied in this software are “as-is” and without warranty of any kind, express, implied or otherwise, including without limitation, any warranty of fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the United States (U.S.) Government be liable to you or anyone else for any direct, special, incidental, indirect or consequential damages of any kind, or any damages whatsoever, including without limitation, loss of profit, loss of use, savings or revenue, or the claims of third parties, whether or not CDC or the U.S. Government has been advised of the possibility of such loss, however caused and on any theory of liability, arising out of or in connection with the possession, use or performance of this software.\nCDC is not responsible for confidentiality or any information shared by the owner or user of the device with other parties. CDC is not responsible for information shared with third parties through loss or theft of the device.\nThis application is not intended to provide medical advice. Any questions regarding a user’s personal medical condition should be directed to the application user’s primary care physician.\nUse of trade names, commercial sources or private organizations is for identification only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and/or CDC.\nSection 508 Accessibility\nThe CDC cannot verify the compliance of documents produced by outside agencies and companies. If you have problems accessing them, please contact the vendor directly or file an accessibility report and mention the name of the file, so we can assist you.\nreCAPTCHA\nWhat is CAPTCHA\nCAPTCHA stands for “Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart” used to prevent automated software from completing a form or accessing a system.\nCAPTCHA Accessibility\nMany sites use the traditional CAPTCHA with distorted text or numbers that must be inputted by a website user. This method presents accessibility challenges making it difficult for persons using screen readers. As a result, CDC has chosen to use the Google reCaptcha to allow the user options to look at a new CAPTCHA challenge and or listen to the current challenge. The interface also allow the user to find out about the CAPTCHA.\nTraditional CAPTCHA\nGoogle's reCAPTCHA\nPage last reviewed:\nDecember 12, 2019 Content source:\nCenters for Disease Control and delivery?\nget my free quote\nOur partners\nSpoil your clients, family and friends with a healthy fruit box gift!\nNever run out of milk in the office again!\nFarm fresh & Australia's finest cherries online\nAustralia's leading online gift hampers\nInformation on Fruits & Other Facts\nDelicious facts about your favourite fruits\n5 Great Reasons to Eat Fruit\nFruit consists largely of water, just like the human body\nFruit is 100% bad-cholesterol free\nFruit stimulates the memory\nFruit has lots of fibre\nFruit makes you feel better\nLearn more about each of the types of fruit that you can receive from Fruit at Work. Simply click on the link next to each picture to find out a little bit more that fruit:\nApples\nBananas\nGrapes\nKiwi Fruit\nMandarins\nMangoes\nNectarines\nOranges\nPeaches\nPears\nPlums\nStrawberries\nApples\nApples come in all shades of reds, greens, yellows.\n7500 varieties of apples are grown throughout the world.\nApples are fat, sodium, and cholesterol free.\nA medium apple is about 80 calories.\nApples are a great source of the fibre pectin. One apple has five grams of fibre.\n25 percent of an apple's volume is air. That is why they float.\nApples ripen six to ten times faster at room temperature than if they were refrigerated.\nThe old saying, “an apple a day, keeps the doctor away”. This saying comes from am old English adage, “To eat an apple before going to bed, will make the doctor beg his bread.”\nDon't peel your apple. Two-thirds of the fibre and lots of antioxidants are found in the peel Antioxidants help to reduce damage to cells, which can trigger some diseases.\nTop of page\nBananas\nBananas are a good source of vitamin C, potassium and dietary fibre.\nBananas have no fat, cholesterol or sodium.\nBananas are great for athletic and fitness activity because they replenish necessary carbohydrates, glycogen and body fluids burned during exercise.\nBananas are available all year-round. They are harvested every day of the year.\nThe banana industry in Australia is well over 100 years old.\nA cluster of bananas is called a hand and consists of 10 to 20 bananas, which are known as fingers.\nWhen you compare it to an apple, it has four times the protein, twice the carbohydrate, three times the phosphorus, five times the vitamin A and iron, and twice the other vitamins and minerals.\nQueensland grower Pacific Coast Eco-Bananas has registered the colour red - applied as a wax on up to a third of the fruit - as a trademark. The grower hopes to become the only grower allowed to use the colour to distinguish and promote its bananas in Australia. It is believed to be the first colour trademark registered for fresh fruit.\nTop of page\nGrapes\nGrapes were first cultivated over 8000 years ago.\nGrapes with black skins are dried to make raisins, whereas sultanas are dried from small seedless green grapes. Americans call all dried grapes ‘raisins’.\nThere are many hundreds of varieties of grapes but the favourites are: Green – Thomson seedless, Waltham Cross and Menindee Seedless,\xa0 Purple/Pink – Muscat, Purple Cornichon, Ribiers, Black Muscat, Flame Seedless and Red Globe.\nGrapes have a high sugar content with half as glucose and half as fructose.\nGrapes also contribute some dietary fibre and vitamin C.\nGrapes also contain adequate amounts of potassium and vitamin A and are low in sodium.\nTop of page\nKiwi Fruit\nKiwi Fruit is actually native to China and were brought to New Zealand by missionaries in the early 20th Century and were originally called Yang Tao. In 1960 they were renamed Chinese Goosberries.\nKiwi Fruit is the most nutrient dense of all the major fruits\nNutrients most commonly associated with Kiwi Fruit including Vitamin C or beta–carotene.\nKiwis are packed with more vitamin C than an equivalent amount of orange.\nKiwi is a good source of the important fat–soluble antioxidant - Vitamin E. This combination of both fat and water soluble antioxidants - Vitamin C, makes Kiwi able to provide free radical protection on all fronts.\nKiwi also has a good source of the minerals: potassium, magnesium, copper and phosphorous.\nKiwi Fruit is high in fibre.\nCalifornia Kiwi Fruit is available November through to May, while the New Zealand crop hits the market in June through to October.\nEnjoying just a couple of Kiwi Fruit each day may significantly lower your risk for blood clots and reduce the amount of fats (triglycerides) in your blood, therefore helping to protect cardiovascular health.\nStore unripe kiwis at room temperature until skin indents slightly when touched. Place kiwi in a paper bag with an apple or banana, or in a ripening bowl to speed ripening. Ripe kiwis can be kept in the refrigerator for up to three weeks.\nTop of page\nMandarins\nMandarins originated in China and were named after the officials of the Imperial Court, the Mandarins.\nThere are three main varieties of Mandarins – Imperial, Ellendale and the Murcott or Honey Tangerine.\nThe mandarin has many names, some of which actually refer to crosses between the mandarin and another citrus fruit.\nMandarins are an excellent source of vitamin C, a good source of B vitamins, low in calories and a good source of fibre.\nTop of page\nMangoes\nMangoes are known as the King of Fruits.\nA mango tree doesn’t produce fruit until it’s about four years old.\nMangoes are picked when mature, and more green than yellow.\nMangoes belong to the same family as the cashew and the pistachio nut.\nMangoes are eaten green in parts of Asia, often sprinkled with a mixture of salt and sugar.\nMangoes are now grown in most tropical countries and are abundant in the northern parts of Australia.\nIn Australia – the most common mango is Kensington Pride or Bowen Special.\nMangoes are an excellent source of vitamin C, beta carotene and other related carotenoids. The deeper the colour of the flesh, the higher the carotenoid level.\nMangoes also supply some dietary fibre.\nTop of page\nNectarines\nNectarines are like peaches without the fuzzy skin.\nNectarines are a great source for vitamin A and various phytochemicals that are good for your eyes and joints.\nNectarines are low in fat, saturated fat free, sodium free, cholesterol free and a great source of vitamin C.\nTo speed up the ripening process, place nectarines in a paper bag and store loosely at room temperature until ripe and then they will keep refrigerated for up to a week.\nTop of page\nOranges\nOne orange supplies a healthy dose of Vitamin C, which plays an important role in cancer prevention, healthy blood circulation and wound healing.\nOranges are a good source of the crucial B-vitamin folate, which is essential in preventing birth defects and fighting heart disease.\nOranges provide more than seven percent of the Daily Value for potassium, which is needed for proper fluid balance.\nNavel oranges are named that because of the belly-button formation opposite the stem end. The bigger the navel in an orange, the sweeter it will be.\nOranges, as well as other fruits, contain a water-soluble fibre called pectin. Studies show that pectin helps reduce blood cholesterol levels. This may explain why individuals who eat several servings daily of fruits, such as oranges, and vegetables have a lower risk for heart disease.\nOranges are high in antioxidants, which neutralize the effects of free radicals, unstable oxygen molecules in your body, believed to cause aging and some diseases.\nAfter chocolate and vanilla, orange is the world's favorite flavor.\nTop of page\nPeaches\nPeaches are very sensitive, bruising easily and should be handled with care.\nPeaches are low in calories and are a good source of vitamin A, phytochemicals and fibre.\nA medium peach packs a powerful 465 IU of vitamin A to combat the effects of aging.\nOther benefits include vitamin B, folic acid, vitamin c, calcium, fibre, potassium and a little zinc.\nThe beta carotene found in peaches also helps build a strong immune system to prevent damage from free radicals and to avert many skin diseases. Beta carotene is a provitamin that the body converts into vitamin A.\nTo ripen peaches, store in a brown bag at room temperature. Once ripe they may be stored in the refrigerator for up to a week, depending on the degree of ripeness.\nTop of page\nPears\nPears are an ideal weight loss food, 98% of their energy is from carbohydrates, which contain half the calories of fat.\nPears are rich in pectin, a soluble fibre which helps the body to eliminate cholesterol and also protects against environmental toxins.\nPears are an excellent source of dietary fibre, vitamin C, copper and vitamin K.\nPears also have good sources of the B complex vitamins and also contain vitamin C. In addition they also contain small amounts of phosphorus and iodine.\nPears help to lower cholesterol.\nDid you know that it takes about 100 to 170 days for a winter pear to develop from a flower?\nTop of page\nPlums\nThere are two major types of plums - European plums and Japanese plums.\nPlums are related to\xa0cherries\xa0and are members of the rose family.\nDid you know that prunes are dried plums?\nPlums have some fructose and sucrose, but most of the sugar is in the form of glucose.\nPlums contain moderate amounts of vitamin C and small quantities of other vitamins and minerals.\nPlums supply moderate quantities of dietary fibre, mostly soluble fibre.\nTop of page\nStrawberries\nA Strawberry has approximately 200 seeds on it.\nStrawberries are not really a berry but a member of the rose family and the real fruits are actually the tiny yellow seeds.\nStrawberries grow wild all over Europe and have been cultivated for the last 700 years.\nStrawberries contact fructose and glucose.\nStrawberries are an excellent source of vitamin C\nThe seeds on a Strawberry provide a good source of dietary fibre.\nStrawberries also contain some folate and one of the B complex vitamins\nTop of page\n© Fruit At Work 2016 Pty Ltd.\nMade by MindArc\n1300 246 256\nAustralia-wide Delivery\nAdelaide\nBlue Mountains\nBrisbane\nCanberra\nGeelong\nGold 5}} additional items, click\nhere to review your cart.\nYour cart is empty.\nHome\n|\nNutrition Topics\n|\nGeneral Nutrition + Wellness\n|\nFood Groups\n|\nFruits\nFruits\nWhat are the benefits of fruit in a healthy eating pattern?\nShare\nFruits are a good source of vitamins and minerals, recognized for their role in preventing vitamin C and vitamin A deficiencies. People who incorporate fruits and vegetables as part of a healthy eating pattern have a reduced risk of some chronic diseases.\xa0USDA's MyPlate encourages filling half of the plate with fruits and vegetables at mealtimes. Fruits are an important part of a healthy eating pattern and the source of many vital nutrients, including potassium, folate (folic acid), and antioxidants including polyphenols. Fruit such as blueberries, cranberries, strawberries\xa0and citrus also contain phytochemicals that are being studied for their added health benefits.\xa0\xa0How Many Servings of Fruit Are Recommended?\xa0Daily Recommendation\xa0\xa0\xa0AgeNo. of servingsChildren2–8 years1–1.5 cupsGirls9–18 years1.5 cupsBoys9–18 years1.5–2 cupsWomen19–30 years2 cupsWomen31+ years1.5 cupsMen19+ years2 cupsEssential Nutrients in FruitThe nutrients in fruit are vital for overall health and maintenance of body systems. The benefits of these nutrients include:\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0Reduced risk of chronic disease: Eating a diet rich in fruit may reduce risk for stroke, cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes.Improved heart health: The potassium in fruit can reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke. Potassium may also reduce the risk of developing kidney stones and help to decrease bone loss.Lower risk of neural tube defects: Folate (folic acid) helps the body form red blood cells. Women of childbearing age who may become pregnant and those in the first trimester of pregnancy need adequate folate. Folate helps prevent neural tube birth defects such as spina bifida.\xa0Protection against cell damage: An eating pattern where fruit is\xa0part of an overall healthy diet provides antioxidants that help repair damage done by free radicals and may protect against certain cancers. It may also have a positive impact on digestive health. Polyphenols are antioxidants\xa0that have been shown to alter gut microecology, or the proportion of healthy versus harmful bacteria.\xa0Find out more about the relationship of a healthy eating pattern and activity on overall health by visiting the\xa0Healthy Eating\xa0page.\xa0References Why is it important to eat fruit? US Department of Agriculture ChooseMyPlate.gov website. https://www.choosemyplate.gov/eathealthy/fruits/fruits-nutrients-health. Accessed October 1, 2019.\xa0Benzie IF, Choi SW. Antioxidants in food: content, measurement, significance, action, cautions, caveats, and research needs. Adv Food Nutr Res. 2014;71:1-53.\xa0 Parkar SG, Stevenson DE, Skinner MA. The potential influence of fruit polyphenols on colonic microflora and human gut health. Int J of Food Microbiol. 2008;124(3):295-298.\n×\nSign in\nEmail address\n*Are you sure you have an account with us?\nPlease enter your email.\nPassword\n{{error}}\nRemember me\nSign in\nForgot your password?\nNew member\nDon’t have an account? Get our life-saving Dinner Daily newsletter. You (and your stomach) can thank us later!\nSign up\nMake Your Edible Summer Spirit Animal\nLuxe and the Lady takes us behind the scenes of her adorable creations.\nrecipe\nMermaid Animal Cake Popsicles\nFin-tastic beauties will be the talk of the town.\nPrepare the cake mix\nFunfetti will make these mermaids gorgeous inside and out.\nAdvertisement\nPopsicle molds aren't just for the freezer\nUsing a piping bag, fill the molds half full and then insert a popsicle stick into each. Pro tip: Spray the molds liberally with nonstick spray to avoid sticking.\nUse these molds to make magnificent mermaids.\nbake & cool the cake pops\nFor #flawless desserts allow the cake popsicles to cool for at least 15 minutes before gently removing from the molds and transferring to a cooling rack to cool completely.\nGive the pops a colorful coat\nDip the pops in candy melts, designating a different color for each animal.\nAdvertisement\nNow for the dainty decor\nUsing fondant, shape the ears and arms for the bunnies, rabbits and cats.\nFondant makes for petite animal paws\nEach fondant decoration can be attached to the cake pops with melted candy melts.\nPlace Ears and Arms onto the cake pops\nNow they're starting to look like animals!\nAdvertisement\nPainting Time\nCreate each animal feature, like the fins and faces, using a toothpick dipped in candy melts.\nGetting a little personality\nUse the same color candy melt as is covering the cake pop to attach the decor.\nGive a Face to the Pops\nPlace the black candy melt eyes, nose and ears on the cake pops to make these adorable-as-heck faces for each animal.\nAdvertisement\nMake Vanilla Buttercream\nBeat softened butter on medium speed until the butter is light and fluffy. Add the vanilla, powdered sugar and milk and mix until airy.\nLight as a cloud\nDivide the fluffy buttercream into three bowls to dye them three pastel hues, like blue purple and pink.\nMake these cute creatures into colorful mermaids\nPipe large round dots, in alternating colors, across the top of each pop to create the mermaid tail.\nAdvertisement\nPerfect pastel Scales\nThen use the back of a spoon to drag the frosting up towards the top of the animal. Continue piping and dragging the frosting as you go, alternating the colors, and slightly overlapping each row.\nA Mermaid Needs her fins\nAttach the candy melt fin to the bottom of her buttercream tail, pressing it in, so it stays.\nNow she can swim\nRepeat the piping of the tail with each animal pop to create your own mermaid menagerie.\nAdvertisement\nReady for their close up\nSweet and smiling, and perfect for any summer party.\nSweet as Can Be\nEmbrace your inner mermaid and make these majestic cake pops.\nDive into this recipe!\nAdvertisement\nKEEP SCROLLING FOR NEXT STORY\nI WANT TO MAKE\nView Suggestions\ngrilling\ntop copycat recipes\nsheet pan dinners\nwatermelon dishes\npasta salad\npantry recipes\nBACK TO TOP\nAll Categories\nSite Map\nAbout Us\nHelp\n© 2020 Scripps Networks, LLC.\nAll Rights Reserved.\nPrivacy Policy\nVisitor Agreement\nClose\nShare this recipe:\n{{title}}\nPinterest\nFacebook\nEmail\nNo Results\nWhoops! There are no results for your search. Please modify your search and try again.\nCancel\nSearch Again\nHey There!\nLooking for one of your favorite recipes? You'll notice that Recipe Box is now called SAVES and your recipes are organized in COLLECTIONS.\nPlus, all of your private notes can now be found directly on the recipe page under the directions.\nOk, Got It!", 'urls': {'https://www.food.com/recipe/mermaid-animal-cake-popsicles-536230', 'https://www.food.com/user/{{=it.userId}}'}}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/recipe/mermaid-animal-cake-popsicles-536230', 'content': "Mermaid Animal Cake Popsicles Recipe\n- Food.com\nRecipesPOPULARSUMMER GRILLINGSearchSavesSign InProfileAdd a RecipeUser SettingsLog Out\nRecipes / Dessert\nMermaid Animal Cake Popsicles\nRecipe by\nluxeandthelady\nMake dessert extra fin-tastic with these light and fluffy funfetti cake pops, they are as delicious as they are adorable!\nREADY IN: 1hr\nYIELD: 20 Cake Pops UNITS: US\nINGREDIENTS Nutrition Confetti Cake Pops\n1\n(15 1/4\nounce) box\ncake mix, Funfetti\n(confetti) 4\nwhole eggs 1\ncup\nwhole milkVanilla Buttercream Frosting\n1\ncup\nunsalted butter, softened\n1\ntablespoon\npure vanilla extract 3 1⁄2\ncups\npowdered sugar 2\ntablespoons\nwhole milk 5\ntablespoons\nfood coloring, Pink icing color, Sky Blue icing color, Lavender icing color and 3 large zip top bags or piping bags Mermaid Decorations\n2\n(12\nounce) bags\nbright white chocolate candy melts 1\n(12\nounce) bag\nblue chocolate candy melts 1\n(12\nounce) bag\nbright pink chocolate candy melts 0.25\n(12\nounce) bag\nlavender chocolate candy melts 0.25\n(12\nounce) bag\nblack chocolate candy melts 4\nounces\nbright white fondant\nsprinkles and frosting, see below\nNUTRITION INFO Serving Size: 1 (2250) g\nServings Per Recipe:\n1\nAMT. PER SERVING % DAILY VALUE\nCalories: 463.8\nCalories from Fat 215 g 46 % Total Fat 23.9 g 36 % Saturated Fat 13.4 g 66 % Cholesterol 70.1 mg\n23 % Sodium 197.1 mg\n8 % Total Carbohydrate\n58.9 g\n19 % Dietary Fiber 0.3 g 1 % Sugars 53.3 g 213 % Protein 4.8 g\n9 %\nDIRECTIONS Confetti Cake Pop Tools:Nonstick baking spray.Popsicle shaped silicone mold.20 popsicle sticks.Mermaid Decoration Tools:Paramount crystals or vegetable oil* (optional to thin and smooth the melts).Black decorating icing fitted with coupler and size 1 small round piping tip.Gold star sprinkles.Pink heart sprinkles.Chocolate sprinkles, long.Multicolored pearl sprinkles (I used blue, white and gold).Toothpicks.Wax paper.Cake Pops:Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F. Generously coat your cake popsicle molds with nonstick baking spray, and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Add the cake mix, eggs, and whole milk to a medium sized mixing bowl and whisk for 2 minutes. Transfer the batter to either a large zip top bag or a piping bag (I like to use a wide mouth glass or jar to hold the bag while filling it with batter). Cut a corner off the bag, and pipe the batter into each popsicle cavity filling half full. Insert a popsicle stick into each, and bake for 12-15 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Allow the cake popsicles to cool for at least 15 minutes before gently removing from the molds and transferring to a cooling rack to cool completely.Buttercream Frosting:You can prepare the frosting for the mermaid’s scales while waiting for the cake pops to cool. Place the softened butter in a mixing bowl, and beat, on medium speed, using a hand mixer or stand mixer for 3 minutes until the butter is light and fluffy. Add the vanilla and mix again until incorporated. Add the powdered sugar and mix again while slowly adding the milk. You will want to start on low then work your way up to about medium speed after adding the powdered sugar or else you will have a cloud of it all over your kitchen! Mix until smooth. Divide the frosting evenly among 3 small bowls. Add a little pink, sky blue, and lavender coloring to each bowl, and mix until combined. You only need a little to achieve a soft shade, and the colors will develop and deepen a bit more as you allow them to sit prior to piping.Mermaid Decorations:Add half a bag of the bright pink and blue candy melts to 2 separate wide mouth glass jars, and then fill the rest of each jar almost completely with white candy melts. Add 1 bag of white candy melts to a third jar. Heat each jar, in the microwave, for 1 minute at 50% power, and then stir. Continue to heat in 30-second intervals, at 50% power, stirring between each set until the candy melts are smooth and fully melted in each jar. Adding white to each color creates a pastel look. If any of your melts are still lumpy looking after melting them you can add about 2 tablespoons of paramount crystals or 1-2 teaspoons of vegetable oil to each jar. Stir it in until completely combined. If any of the melts harden while working just reheat them in 30-second intervals until smooth again.Bunny Mermaids:Dip all of your bunny cake pops into the melted blue candy melts. Allow the excess to drip off of the top of each before placing onto a piece of wax paper to set. If you notice any air bubbles in the coating you can pop them immediately with a toothpick. While waiting for the first coating to harden, break off about a fourth of the fondant to form the ears and paws. Roll little balls of fondant in between your thumb and pointer finger to make the paws. The ears are made by creating teardrop shapes and pinching the tops to form a point. Use a little more of the candy melts like “glue” to attach the ears and paws to the cake pops (you may have to hold the ears on for a few seconds until they set). Once all of the fondant pieces have set to the cake pops dip each pop again into the blue melts (allowing for the excess to drip off). Place them back onto the wax paper to harden completely. If you are having trouble getting the ears to stay straight you can use a marshmallow underneath the ears to prop them up while they harden. Use a little of the melted pink candy melts to make the fins, and also to add a little pink to the inside of each ear. Just dip a toothpick into the melts and use it to “draw” the design (like a flattened heart shape) onto wax paper and allow to set. Break off another smaller piece of the white fondant and mix a little of the pink icing coloring into it until combined. Form tiny balls of the pink fondant and place them onto a piece of wax paper. Flatten each ball out with your fingers to form the cheeks for each animal popsicle. Once your bunnies have set you can add the buttercream mermaid scales (no fancy piping skills required). I like to use a toothpick to draw a guideline onto each pop for the top of the mermaid’s tail. Transfer each color of buttercream frosting into either a piping bag or large zip top bag and cut about 1/2 an inch off of the corner. It’s easiest if you start with the cake pops upside down (the stick pointing up). Pipe large round dots, in alternating colors, across the top of each pop. Then use the back off a spoon to drag the frosting up towards the top of the animal. Continue piping and dragging the frosting as you go, alternating the colors, and slightly overlapping each row until you reach the guideline (you should have about 3 rows of scales on each cake pop). Push each fin into the buttercream scales to hold them in place. Turn the cake pops right side up, and use pearl sprinkles to form a line across the top. Use decorating icing to add the eyes and nose onto each, and a little more of the blue candy melts to attach the seashell or heart bras and hair accessories.Cat Mermaids:Dip all of your cat cake pops into the melted pink candy melts as you did for the bunnies. Place onto wax paper to set. Break off 1/4 piece white fondant and form the paws just like the bunnies, and the ears by pressing little balls of the fondant into a triangle between your thumbs and pointer fingers. Press down on each gently to flatten. Attach the fondant pieces to each cake pop with pink melts, and once set, dip again into the pink candy melts. Make lavender mermaid fins by heating a little of the lavender melts along with a handful of white melts in a small heatproof bowl in 30-second intervals. Once the final coating on the cake pops has hardened you can decorate them just as you did for the bunnies.Panda Mermaids:Dip all of the remaining cake pops into the melted white candy melts just like you did for the other 2 animals. Form paws using a little of the white fondant and attach with the white candy melts. Once the fondant pieces have set you can dip the cake pops again. The panda’s ears and eyes are made using black candy melts. Melt 1/4 bag black candy melts as you did for the other colors, and then draw 2 semi circles for the ears, and 2 ovals for the eyes for each, using a toothpick, onto wax paper. Once the coating on the pops and the black candy melts have set you can use a little more of the white candy melts to attach the ears and eyes to each cake pop, and to draw the lashes onto the eyes. Decorate as you did for the other animals, admire your mer-mazing cake popsicles, and enjoy!\nYOU'LL ALSO LOVE\n12 Fun Popsicle Recipes\n12 photos\nTop 100 Weeknight Dinner Recipes\n42 Best Grilled Main Dishes\nOur 75 Top-Rated Recipes of All Tim...\nView All Recipes\nI Want to Discover\nView Suggestions\nBACK TO TOP\n© 2020\nScripps Networks, LLC.\nAll Rights Reserved.Privacy PolicyVisitor Agreement", 'urls': {'https://www.food.com/user', 'https://www.food.com/upload/recipe', 'https://www.food.com/user/settings'}}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/user/settings', 'content': 'Notification\nThis site is not available in your country', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/upload/recipe', 'content': 'Notification\nThis site is not available in your country', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/user', 'content': 'Notification\nThis site is not available in your country', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/ideas/top-grilling-recipes-6974#c-810376', 'content': 'Top 100 Grilling Recipes - Food.com\nRecipes\nPOPULAR\nSUMMER GRILLING\nSearch\nStumped for dinner? Get our life-saving Dinner Daily newsletter. You (and your stomach) can thank us later!\nSign up\nPART OF Summer Grilling\nTop 100 Grilling Recipes\nIt\'s grilling season, and something about those gorgeous grill marks make just about anything tasty. I used smoked turkey sausage and thyme instead of rosemary. The sausage imparts so much flavor!”\n-kris.hodges_12155422\nrecipe\nSpicy Beef Flatbread With Yogurt & Cucumbers\n"Where do I begin? 'https://www.food.com/recipe/grilled-potatoes-249021', 'content': 'Grilled Potatoes Recipe\n- Food.com\nRecipesPOPULARSUMMER GRILLINGSearchSavesSign InProfileAdd a RecipeUser SettingsLog Out\nRecipes / Potato\nCommunity Pick Grilled Potatoes\n(47)\nRecipe by\ndiner524\nWhen it is hot outside, who wants to heat up the oven and the house.\nThese are great to go along side with any meat or fish dish. I clipped this recipe out of a Taste of Home Magazine.\nUpdated 7/25/11, I now have made the recipe and the whole family loved the potatoes this way. I also added onion, but the recipe doesn\'t call for it. To really make it easy, I used &quot;Simply Potatoes&quot; already peeled and sliced potatoes, and used an 8&quot;x8&quot; foil pan; so quick and simple, yet so flavorful.\n51\nPeople talking\nReviews, Tweaks & More\nReviews, Tweaks & More\nREADY IN: 35mins SERVES: 6-8\nUNITS: US\nINGREDIENTS Nutrition\n6\nmedium\nbaking potatoes, sliced\n1\nteaspoon\ngarlic powder 1\nteaspoon\nseasoning salt (to taste) 1⁄2\nteaspoon\npaprika 1⁄4\ncup\nparmesan cheese, grated\n6\ntablespoons\nbutter\nNUTRITION INFO Serving Size: 1 (116) g\nServings Per Recipe:\n6\nAMT. PER SERVING % DAILY VALUE\nCalories: 240.3\nCalories from Fat 115 g 48 % Total Fat 12.9 g 19 % Saturated Fat 8.1 g 40 % Cholesterol 34.2 mg\n11 % Sodium 171 mg\n7 % Total Carbohydrate\n28 g\n9 % Dietary Fiber 2.6 g 10 % Sugars 1.3 g 5 % Protein 4.4 g\n8 %\nDIRECTIONS On half of a 24-inch piece of heavy-duty aluminum foil, arrange the potato slices in overlapping rows.Combine garlic powder, seasoned salt, paprika and Parmesan cheese; sprinkle over the potatoes.Dot with butter.Seal foil over potatoes.Grill over medium heat for 30 minutes or until tender, turning once.Note:\nI cook it off the direct heat so I don\'t burn them, and I cook them for about 45 to 60 minutes.\nYOU\'LL ALSO LOVE\nTop 100 Grilling Recipes\n100 photos\nGrilled Parmesan Potatoes\nby\ndiner524\n(17)\nGrilled "baked" Potatoes\nby\nbabygirl65\n(5)\nGrilled Potatoes\nby\nJane Rhodes-Williams\n(25)\nView All Recipes\nI Want to Discover\nView Suggestions\nBACK TO TOP\n© 2020\nScripps Networks, LLC.\nAll Rights Reserved.Privacy PolicyVisitor Agreement', 'urls': {'https://www.food.com/user', 'https://www.food.com/upload/recipe', 'https://www.food.com/user/settings'}}, {'url': 'https://www.food.com/recipe/grilled-basil-lemon-chicken-241869', 'content': "Grilled Basil Lemon Chicken Recipe\n- Food.com\nRecipesPOPULARSUMMER GRILLINGSearchSavesSign InProfileAdd a RecipeUser SettingsLog Out\nRecipes / Poultry\nGrilled Basil Lemon Chicken\n(16)\nRecipe by\nMarraMamba\nA simple dish that I use for basil lemon chicken panini the day after. You can use tenders or chicken scaloppine as well.\nThanks for catching my omission of the basil in the directions, I have fixed it.\n19\nPeople talking\nReviews, Tweaks & More\nReviews, Tweaks & More\nREADY IN: 20mins SERVES: 4\nUNITS: US\nINGREDIENTS Nutrition\n4\nboneless chicken breasts 2\nlarge\nlemons 2\ngarlic cloves, coarsely chopped\n1\ntablespoon\nolive oil\nsalt & pepper 2\nteaspoons\nfresh basil, chopped\n(or 1/2 tsp dried)\nNUTRITION INFO Serving Size: 1 (192) g\nServings Per Recipe:\n4\nAMT. Then, he makes cous cous and citrus salad and shiitake mushroom curry.\nS2:E4\n22mins\nEpisode 3\nJamie meets one of the oldest people in the world in South Korea. The menu includes sweet potato and black bean burritos.\nS3:E2\n20mins\nEpisode 10\nJames travels to Yorkshire to explore why its unique landscape produces distinct regional ingredients. And download Cooking for iPhone and iPad in the App Store.SIGN UPAdvertisementContinue reading the main storyFollow Usnytfoodtwitter page for nytfoodnytcookinginstagram page for nytcookingnytcookingfacebook page for nytcookingnytcookingpinterest page for nytcookingSite IndexSite Information Navigation©\xa02020\xa0The New York Times CompanyNYTCoContact UsWork with usAdvertiseT Brand StudioYour Ad ChoicesPrivacyTerms of ServiceTerms of SaleSite MapHelpSubscriptions', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.eatthis.com/classic-comfort-foods-no-longer-eaten', 'content': '15 Classic Comfort Foods You Haven\'t Eaten in Years | Eat This Not That\nToggle navigation\nWeight Loss\nHealthy Eating\nRecipes\nRestaurants\nGroceries\nETNT Health\nFood & Nutrition News\nThe Books\nThe Magazine\nThe Podcast\nThe Game\nThe Newsletter\nSkip to content\nHealthy Eating\n15 Forgotten Comfort Foods We Need to Bring Back ASAP\nThese classic dishes used to be Americans\' go-to foods, but can you remember the last time you had one of them?\nBy\nLaurie Wilson\nApril 22, 2020\nComfort food and nostalgia go hand and hand. It\'s no surprise that classic comfort foods remind you of your childhood. You grew up with your mom making your favorite soothing meal as a consolation prize when you deserved a reward, when you weren\'t feeling swell, or when you just needed a hug.\nOf course, dishes like mac \'n cheese, mashed potatoes, and meatloaf have stood the test of time and are still giving comfort to this day. However, there are countless once-upon-a-time dishes that did their job well, but for whatever reason, are no longer around for the party. Take a trip down memory lane with these comfort foods you haven\'t eaten in years.\n1\nChicken a la King\nShutterstockQueen of the comfort food dinners in the early 20th century, especially in winter, this steamy rich dish was created with diced chicken, mushrooms, veggies, and sherry cream sauce and served over toast or biscuits. It was crowned in the 1800s, appearing on menus in upscale restaurants, namely in New York City. But in the \'50s, Chicken a la King held court in households across the nation. Turkey a la King was just as indulgent, but neither are served as often today as a similar classic: chicken pot pie.\nWe love this Chicken a la King recipe from Taste & Tell.\nRELATED: Sign up for our newsletter to get daily recipes and food news in your inbox!\n2\nEgg Cream\nShutterstockWith Jewish and New York City roots, this drink doesn\'t actually contain eggs or cream.\xa0It was a regionally revered beverage made with chocolate, seltzer, and milk and served often at soda fountains and in luncheonettes.\nWe love this recipe for a Nutella Egg Cream from My Name is Yeh.\nRELATED: Your ultimate restaurant and supermarket survival guide is here!\n3\nFluffernutter Sandwiches\nShutterstockMarshmallow fluff is the quintessential feel-good food. I have a friend who always travels with a jar of the stuff—she eats it with a spoon straight out of the jar. In the \'60s and \'70s, peanut butter and marshmallow fluff slathered between two slices of white bread became a comfort sandwich for kids, but not so much anymore (perhaps because many of us are watching our sugar intake). By the way, National Fluffernutter Day is October 8, if you need an excuse to eat this classic sandwich.\nWant to give the old recipe a new spin? Try this Fluffernutter Panini recipe from Taste & Tell.\nRELATED: Click here for all of our latest coronavirus coverage.\n4\nTapioca Pudding\nShutterstockThis is your grandmother\'s comfort food: a pudding made with tapioca and cream or milk, served cold or (better yet) warm. Tapioca is a starch extracted from the cassava root; these days, you\'ll find it in bubble tea more often than in pudding.\nWe love this recipe for Vanilla Honey Tapioca Pudding from Foraged Dish.\n5\nBaked Apples\nShutterstockThis comfort fruit dish, especially popular in the fall, was in its heyday in the \'50s. It was one of the "healthier" comfort foods and is typically baked with cinnamon, sugar and butter.\nWe love this recipe for Cinnamon Baked Apples from Minimalist Baker.\nRELATED: This 7-day smoothie diet will help you shed those last few pounds.\n6\nWelsh Rarebit\nShutterstockWelsh rarebit was the ultimate comfort food dinner: a quick meal built with toasted bread blanketed with a cheesy sauce (sometimes made with beer) and then baked or broiled. (My dad used the Stouffer\'s boxed version, which he would doctor with bacon and tomatoes.) It was a savory comfort dish that\'s sadly vanished from dining tables.\nMore on Dessert\nWhat Happens to Your Body When You Eat Dessert Every Day\nIndulging your sweet cravings every day can have disastrous effects on your health.\n50 Amazing Summer Dessert Recipes\nBonus: They\'re actually healthy, too.\nHow to Make the Best Old-Fashioned Milkshake\nThese will rival the ones at the ice cream shop.\nThe Unhealthiest Desserts in America\nThese are just the worst of the worst!\n15 Delicious Vegan Ice Creams\nEven dairy lovers will want to try these.\nWe like this Welsh Rarebit Recipe from I Am a Food Blog.\n7\nTuna Noodle Casserole\nShutterstockThis dish evokes childhood memories, and maybe that\'s the most comforting thing about it. It was a family meal featuring canned tuna fish, shredded cheese, canned veggies like peas or corn, and that clutch Cream of Mushroom soup. A can of fried onions sprinkled on top gave this casserole its comfort crunch.\nWe like this Tuna Noodle Casserole recipe from Ambitious Kitchen.\nRELATED: Learn how to harness the power of tea to lose weight.\n8\nRice Pudding\nShutterstockRice pudding has a storied history and has had a place at the table in regions throughout the world for centuries. In the United States, rice pudding is commonly made with rice, milk, butter, and cinnamon. It\'s particularly comforting when served warm, and it\'s made even more gratifying with the addition of whiskey or maple syrup.\nWe love this Creamy Rice Pudding recipe from Lil\' Luna.\n9\nTV Dinners\nShutterstockWhen the \'rents went out for the evening, it was TV dinners for the kiddos. Today, it\'s more like take-out or delivery night. TV dinners were a fun-loving meal where you could eat on a TV tray, not at the dinner table, and watch the night\'s television lineup (on 13 channels). Swanson\'s Hungry Man Turkey TV Dinner was a popular dinner in the \'70s, and so was Swanson\'s Salisbury Steak TV Dinner with its tiny compartments of peas, mashed potatoes and cobbler dessert.\nReady for more throwbacks? These Old TV Dinners Will Make You So Nostalgic For Your Childhood.\n10\nRoot Beer Float\nShutterstockA foamy dessert made with root beer and generous scoops of vanilla ice cream, a root beer float was often shared on first dates with high school sweethearts, or with grandpa at the soda fountain.\nWe love this Classic Root Beer Float recipe from Diethood.\n11\nGrandma\'s Corn Pudding\nShutterstockTalk about Southern comfort—even the name of this dish is consoling. It was once very popular in the South and is created using corn, eggs, milk or heavy cream, sugar, and butter. We think it\'s still \'gram-worthy today.\nWe like this Creamy Corn Pudding recipe from Cupcakes & Kale Chips.\n12\nPudding\nShutterstockA dessert that seemed to melt away emotional and physical pain, popular flavors were chocolate, vanilla, and butterscotch. And banana pudding with Nilla Wafers in the \'50s was a hit, especially in the South. Now, you\'re more likely to find pudding cups in hospital cafeterias before ever whipping it up at home yourself.\nWe love this recipe for Homemade Chocolate Pudding from Five Heart Home.\n13\nJell-O\nShutterstockWiggly, squiggly, sugary, and colorful, there were no redeeming healthy qualities to this gelatinous dessert. It was a desired comfort food whether as a snack at home, or even at a holiday meal in the form of a Jell-O salad mold made in a Bundt pan.\nTry using the classic treat to make this pretty Stained Glass Jello recipe from Gimme Some Oven.\n14\nFranks and Baked Beans\nShutterstockA comfort supper, especially in New England, this meal was inexpensive and hearty. It\'s made, of course, with frankfurters, but the secret was in those beans, typically simmered in sweet molasses. Throw in some brown bread (homemade in a can or store-bought) and you\'ve got a traditional Saturday night in New England meal.\nNot sure what brand to buy? We Taste-Tested 10 Different Kinds of Baked Beans—Here Are the Best.\n15\nSloppy Joes\nShutterstockJust the idea that it was a sloppy dish was comforting to kids—it was a license to let the meat tumble down their chin and into their lap, at no fault of their own. The loose meat sandwich, which was very popular in the Midwest, was made with a blend of ground beef, onions, tomato sauce or ketchup and Worcestershire sauce and then slopped on a hamburger bun. Who\'s Joe? Who knows.\nWe love this Vegan Sloppy Joe recipe from Minimalist Baker.\nNow that you\'ve taken a trip down memory lane, why not add one of these throwback dishes to your meal plan for the week?\nShe Lost 100 Pounds—And Shows You How!\nRegistered Dietitian and Nutritionist Ilana Muhlstein lost her weight and kept it off—and in You Can Drop It!, she\'ll show you how to lose it, too. More than 240,000 clients have chosen her program—and now it’s yours to keep.\nOrder Yours Now\nFiled UnderDessert\nRead This Next\nHealthy Eating\n15 Classic American Desserts No Longer Made\nHave you ever seen these on a menu?\nHealthy Eating\n50 Vintage-Inspired Recipes to Try\nThese recipes deserve a spot on your dinner table.\nHealthy Eating\nHow to Read Vintage Cookbooks Online for Free\nDuke University digitized 82 old-school tomes.\nHealthy Eating\n50 Vintage-Inspired Recipes for Spring\nTry these nostalgic meals at home this season.\nHealthy Eating\n20 Classic Breakfast Dishes No One Eats Anymore\nThese morning meals have been retired.\nHealthy Eating\n50 Old-School Dinner Recipes to Try\nThey\'re called classics for a reason!\nHealthy Eating\nWe Miss These 33 Childhood Snacks\nGet ready for a serious dose of nostalgia.\nHealthy Eating\n27 Foods That Were Crazy Popular in the \'90s\nGushers vs. Fruit by the Foot is still a great debate.\nMore in Healthy Eating\n26 Anti-Aging Foods to Keep You Young\n20 Foods to Help You Live Longer\n5 Best Food-Themed Face Masks to Buy\n20 Habits That Age You\nThis Is Secretly What\'s in Your Hot Dog\nFacebook\nTwitter\nInstagram\nPinterest\nAbout Us\nOur Advisory Board\nSubscribe\nNewsletters\nPartner Sites\nPrivacy Policy\nTerms and Conditions\nAdvertise\nFAQ\nContact Us\nSubscribe to our daily newsletter\nGet the best food tips and diet advice every day.\n© 2020 Galvanized Media. By making informed choices, you can lose weight and reshape your body—without restrictions or fads.\nQ: Do companies pay to be featured on the site?\nA: We may accept free samples of food and products for review; however, unless an article explicitly states it is sponsored content, we do not accept payment in exchange for coverage. Our opinions and reporting are our own and are completely objective.\xa0That goes for every book, magazine, ebook and PDF, too.\nEat This, Not That! does have affiliate relationships, so we may get a small share of the revenue if you purchase an item by clicking on a link shared on EatThis.com. Items are sold by the retailer, not by Eat This, Not That!\nQ: How does this site work?\nA: Eat This, Not That! is the country\'s most extensive source of nutrition information for your favorite restaurants and supermarket foods. You\'ll find the categories of Weight Loss, Health, Restaurants, Supermarkets, Family and Recipes. We add new stories, roundups and comparisons daily. Check back often!\nQ: How do I ask a question or make a suggestion?\nA: If you have a specific question or suggestion for the editors, please send it to editors@eatthis.com. Because of the volume of mail we receive, we cannot guarantee a personal reply to any questions.\nQ: I can\'t find the restaurant or supermarket item I\'m looking for. Help?\nA: We are always working on adding new restaurant and supermarket items to the site. If you\'d like to suggest something, please send it to editors@eatthis.com.\nQ: How can I change my e-mail address for the Eat This, Not That! newsletter?\nA: Add the new address to the sign-up form here. Then, at the bottom of your current newsletter, find the "Unsubscribe, or Tell us a Concern" portion, and click the link that allows you to unscubscribe your old email address.\nQ: I\'m having a technical problem or I notice something buggy with the site. What can I do?\nA: Our site is currently undergoing a relaunch, so you may find pages without photos or broken links. Shop\nQ: How is secure is the purchase process?\nA: We use industry standard encryption and secure connection (https), and use partners technologies which adhere to the highest security standards.\nQ: Do you do anything with my information?\nA: Your information is only used and saved for purposes of using the shop site.\nQ: Do I need to create an account?\nA: You have the option of creating an account or checking out as a guest.\nQ: Where do I go for help or questions?\nA: We\'re here to make sure you are satisfied with your experience. Please email us at help@eatthis.com.\nQ: I bought a product. How long will it take to arrive?\nA: If you purchased a print book, your order will arrive in two to three weeks. If you purchased a digital download, you will be able to download it immediately after purchase.\nQ: What is your refund policy?\nA: We offer a 90-day return policy for any printed product if your item arrives damaged or you are dissatified. Please email help@eatthis.com with your return request and proof of purchase.\nPDF Book Purchases\nQ: How do I download my PDF and where do I find my password?\nA: When you complete your purchase, your download link and password will be supplied on the following page on the shop site. It will also be sent to you in a confirmation email. If you register on the site it will also be stored in your account history.\nQ: How do I view my PDF and save it for later use?\nA: Virtually all computers, tablets and phones have the ability to save downloaded PDFs, and to view them. Your device should automatically open the PDF in a default viewer when you download, or when you tap or click on the PDF file. Most computers will save the PDF to a default downloads location for future use, or will ask you where you\'d like to save it. iPads and iPhones typically open PDFs in the browser, where you can bookmark it, or use controls to save it in iBooks.\nQ: Am I permitted to print my PDF?\nA: Yes, you may print the PDF.\nQ: Can I use my PDF on multiple devices?\nA: Yes, you can use your PDF on multiple devices, but you may not share the PDF.\nOther Products\nQ: How can I purchase Eat This, Not That! books or other products?\nA: We\'re launching new products and adding them to the shop site, so please visit again soon. (ii) you have never felt chest pain when engaging in physical activity; (iii) you have not experienced chest pain when not engaged in physical activity at any time within the past month; (iv) you have never lost your balance because of dizziness and you have never lost consciousness; (v) you do not have a bone or joint problem that could be made worse by a change in your physical activity; (vi) your physician is not currently prescribing drugs for your blood pressure or heart condition; (vii) you do not have a history of high blood pressure, and no one in your immediate family has a history of high blood pressure or heart problems; and (viii) you do not know of any other reason you should not exercise; or (B) your physician has specifically approved of your use of the Sites and the Services.\nYou further affirm that either (A) all of the following statements are true: (i) you are not allergic to nuts, eggs, dairy products or any other foods; (ii) you are not presently following a diet plan provided to you by a physician or other medical professional for health reasons; and (iii) you have not been medically diagnosed as suffering from diabetes, hypoglycemia, heart disease, high cholesterol or high blood pressure; ETNT! LLC (hereinafter "Company", "us", "our", "we") recognizes the importance of protecting the privacy of all users who visit the website located at www.eatthis.com (the "Information Site"), and its affiliate website, www.shop.eatthisnotthat.com (the "Shopping Site, and together with the Information Site, the "Sites"). All "Personal Information" that you give to us will be protected and kept confidential among Company and its affiliated companies in accordance with the provisions set forth in this Privacy Policy. When we use the term "Personal Information," we mean any information that can be used to personally identify or contact a specific individual, such as a name, address(es) (e.g., home, shipping, billing address etc.), telephone number or email address. Our Privacy Policy applies only to such Personal Information as is collected by us via the Sites and does not extend to any other website, whether or not it is affiliated or linked to the Sites or to Company. Company reserves the right to change our Privacy Policy at any time. Each time you use the Sites, you are accepting and consenting to the practices described in this Privacy Policy and in the Terms and Conditions, the current version of our Privacy Policy and Terms and Conditions will apply, and you should review our Privacy Policy and Terms and Conditions for any changes that may have been made since your last visit to the Sites. All capitalized terms used in our Privacy Policy that are defined in the Terms and Conditions and not otherwise defined herein shall have the same respective meanings given to them in the Terms and Conditions.\nPersonal Information. Personal information may be collected about you ("Personal Information") when you voluntarily register with the Shopping Site, subscribe to the newsletter with the Information Site, or contact the Company via the Site in order to purchase products or to receive newsletters from us with information regarding, without limitation, new product launches and/or special events or notifying you of other Company promotions ("Promotional Material"), or when you otherwise voluntarily provide Personal Information when you use or visit the Sites. Company may use the Personal Information you provide for various purposes, such as to create a personal customer profile in order to let you know of products, services or events that may be of interest to you. However, Company will neither disclose nor sell any Personal Information about you to a party unaffiliated or unrelated to Company except (i) to comply with applicable laws, regulations, subpoenas or court orders or otherwise respond to government inquiries, (ii) protect the rights or property of Company or its affiliated or related entities or (iii) if Company reasonably believes that you have used information from the Sites in order to commit unlawful acts or acts that may endanger the health and/or safety of any person or the public. Company may appoint third-party service providers to administer and/or operate certain functions or services relating to the Sites or Company\'s operations and businesses, the performance of which may require or be facilitated by a transfer of the Personal Information submitted by you. Any such transfer shall be under strict confidentiality and security obligations and for the sole purpose of the performance of those obligations.\nAdditional Privacy Protection for Children Using the Internet. Company does not intend to collect any Personal Information from children under the age of 13 years old. If we learn that a child under the age of 13 has provided Personal Information to any of the Sites, we will promptly remove such information from the Sites\' files.\nAggregate Information. Company may also collect aggregate information, which may be used in a collective manner, and from which no individual person can be identified. The types of aggregate information we may collect may include frequency of visits to the Sites, products purchased, search terms entered, Site pages most frequently accessed and/or location, age or gender of Users and/or Members and other commercial information (collectively, "Aggregate Information"). By knowing more about the general profile of our Users and/or Members (without identifying any specific individual\'s characteristics), we believe we can improve your experience on our Sites. Aggregate Information collected on the Sites may be used and disclosed in any way. For example, we may collect and analyze collected Aggregate Information to determine how many visitors arrived at certain pages of the Sites, how long they stayed on those pages, and where they went afterwards. This information allows us to determine which pages might be the most interesting to our visitors and enables us to provide them with a better and richer experience on the Sites. Additionally, we may use Aggregate Information to improve the performance of our Sites, and to customize the content and layout of our Sites pages for you.\nInformation that is Publicly Available. When you become a User and/or Member (as defined in the Terms and Conditions), information about your account activity may be provided to other Users and/or Members. IF YOU CHOOSE TO MAKE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION, ANY COMMUNICATIONS OR OTHER INFORMATION PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH OR ON THE SITES, YOU DO SO AT YOUR OWN RISK.\nUse of Cookies and Other Tracking Technologies. Cookies are pieces of information that any website may transfer to your browser that are then stored in your computer system. For example, the Site will place a cookie on a visitor\'s computer when he/she visits the Site. The next time that person visits the Site using the same computer, our server will recognize the cookie and the visitor. The deposit of cookies by the Site will allow Company to save your preferences for your next visit. Company\'s cookies may also measure the general activity on the Site, which allows us to determine which areas and features are most popular. This information allows Company to make improvements to our Site. Most web browsers are set up to accept cookies. You can, however, reset your browser to refuse all cookies or to indicate when a cookie is being sent, and/or you may delete cookies at any time.\nEuropean Economic Area Residents. If you reside in a country in the European Economic Area (EEA), then under the GDPR and applicable data protection laws you have the rights, among other things, to access your personal data, have us erase it, and/or restrict its further processing.\nSecurity. Protecting your information is of primary concern to Company. Company stores the information that it collects on a secure server. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no transmission of information over the Internet is guaranteed to be completely secure. It is possible that third parties not under the control of Company may be able to access or intercept transmissions unlawfully. Although Company will use all reasonable attempts to keep your information secure, Company cannot absolutely guarantee that security. As such, any information that you transmit to us is at your own risk.\nLinks to Other Sites. The Sites may contain links to websites other than the Sites. Those sites may have their own privacy policies or no privacy policy at all. Neither Company nor any of our service providers have any responsibility for those sites, and Company provides these links solely for the convenience of our visitors. These sites may send their own cookies to you and may collect information and use it in a way inconsistent with this Privacy Policy. If you provide Personal Information to any such third-party website, your transaction will occur on such third party\'s website (not the Sites) and the Personal Information you provide will be collected by, and controlled by the privacy policy of, that third party. We encourage you to read the legal notices posted on those third-party websites, including their privacy policies. The Game\n4+\nGalvanized Brands LLC\n1.7, 40 Ratings\nFree\nOffers In-App Purchases\nScreenshots\niPhone\niPad\nDescription\nIt\'s the all-new, good for you, and completely fun, EAT THIS, NOT THAT! THE GAME!Think you can spot the safe food from the gut bomb? EAT THIS, NOT THAT! THE GAME challenges your armchair nutritionist skills with face-offs of food from all the famous fast-food joints and grocery aisles.\nIn this fun, quippy and incredibly informative app, you\'ll tap through round after round of food items, adding to your score as you tap the healthier item. As the timer runs, more and more nutritional info appears to inform your choice. But the quicker you are, the more points you earn. After each tap, the correct "Eat this" and Not That" labels are revealed, along with the fascintating, devastating explanations of why you should—or shouldn\'t.Rack up your score and learn what habits you need to change. Some of the info is incredibly surprising!Optional Hints: Feeling lucky? Play the game without hints, and see if you can guess by image and name alone.Lots of Free Gameplay: At the end of each round, retry that category to improve your score, or try one of the other categories.• Breakfast • Lunch • Dinner • DessertCome back to the app often—we\'re adding new swaps all the time.Join the food revolution, brought to you by Eat This, Not That! 'content': 'Food\neatright\neatright Pro\neatright Store\neatrightCPE\nMedia\nFind an Expert\nSubmit\nSearch\nSubmit\nMenu\nFood\nHealth\nFitness\nKids\nFor Kids\nKnow More\nCategories\nFor Baby\nFor daily life.\nDietary Guidelines and MyPlate\nEat Right at School\nEating as a Family\nHealthy Eating\nNutrition Facts and Food Labels\nVegetarian and Special Diets\nPlanning and Prep\nNavigate grocery store aisles, make healthful choices and get nutritious meals to the table.\nCooking Tips and Trends\nEat Right on a Budget\nRecipes\nSmart Shopping\nSnack and Meal Ideas\nVitamins and Supplements\nLearn about types of vitamins, nutrients and minerals and when supplements might be needed.\nDietary Supplements\nNutrient Rich Foods\nVitamins and Nutrients\nResources\nLearn more about Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, All Rights Reserved.\nConnect with Us\nPinterest\nfacebook\nLinkedIn\nTwitter\nYoutube\nContact Us\nEditorial Policy\nMedia\nPrivacy Policy\nThis website uses cookies.\nWe use cookies to optimize and personalize your experience, provide relevant content and analyze online traffic. We also share information with our analytics and website partners, who may use it to inform decisions about current or future services. By clicking “Agree,” you consent to use cookies if you continue to our website. You can manage your cookie settings by clicking the "cookie preferences" button.\nI Agree\nCookie Preferences\nThis website uses cookies.\nWe use cookies to optimize and personalize your experience, provide relevant content and analyze online traffic. We also share information with our analytics and website partners, who may use it to inform decisions about current or future services.\xa0By clicking “Agree” below, you consent to use cookies if you continue to our website.\nYou can customize your cookie preferences by using the settings next to "Analytical Cookies" and "Marketing Cookies." Click the "Save Preferences" button to save your customized settings. For more detailed information on the cookies we use, please visit the Academy\'s\xa0Privacy Policy.\nI Agree\nNecessary Cookies\nNecessary cookies enable core functionality. These plugins place cookies so that you can correctly view how many times a page has been shared.\nSave Preferences', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.takingcharge.csh.umn.edu/how-does-food-impact-health', 'content': 'How Does Food Impact Health? | Taking Charge of Your Health & Wellbeing\nSkip to main content\nMain navigationMain content\nUniversity of Minnesotahttp://twin-cities.umn.edu/612-625-5000\nGo to the U of M home page\nOne Stop\nMyU\nSearch\nPrimary links\nbe MINDFUL\nExplore\nBenefits\nGet Started\nHow It Works\nEvidence\nAddress Stress\nCope with Pain\nlive HEALTHY\nDiet & Nutrition\nPhysical Activity & Fitness\nSleep\nStress Mastery\nThoughts & Emotions\nHealthcare\ncreate CONNECTION\nPersonal Relationships\nYour Community\nfeel SAFE\nBe Safe Wherever You Are\nFace Fear and Anxiety\nRethink Money\nfind MEANING\nLife Purpose\nSpirituality\nhealing ENVIRONMENTS\nAt Home\nIn Nature\nOur Planet\nSecondary links\nManage Health Conditions\n×\nAnxiety\nArthritis\nAutism Spectrum Disorders\nBack Pain\nCOVID-19 and Anxiety\nCancer\nChildbirth\nDepression\nDiabetes\nEnd of Life and Hospice Care\nHeadaches\nHeart Disease\nIrritable Bowel Syndrome\nMenopause\nMigraines\nPregnancy\nTry Holistic Practices\n×\nWhat Are Holistic Practices?\nAcupuncture and Traditional Chinese Medicine\nAromatherapy\nAyurvedic Medicines\nBotanical Medicine\nChiropractic\nClinical Hypnosis\nCraniosacral Therapy\nCreative Therapies\nFood as Medicine\nGuided Imagery\nHealing Environments\nHealing Touch\nHolistic Pregnancy and Childbirth\nIntuition in Healthcare\nMassage Therapy\nMind-Body Therapies\nMindfulness\nNaturopathy\nOsteopathic Medicine\nPrayer\nQigong\nReflexology\nReiki\nShamanism\nShiatsu\nSocial Support\nTherapeutic Touch\nTibetan Medicine\nYoga\nMenu\nSearch\nHow Does Food Impact Health?\nMore info on this topic\nFood As Medicine Home\nImpact of food\nWhat to eat\nWhy nutrition advice changes\nWhat specific foods do\nEat for specific conditions\nMindful eating\nMediterranean diet\nFood and the environment\nMore food resources\nThe food we eat gives our bodies the "information" and materials they need to function properly. If we don\'t get the right information, our metabolic processes suffer and our health declines.\nIf we get too much food, or food that gives our bodies the wrong instructions, we can become overweight, undernourished, and at risk for the development of diseases and conditions, such as arthritis, diabetes, and heart disease.\nIn short, what we eat is central to our health. \xa0Consider that in light of Webster\'s definition of medicine: "The science and art dealing with the maintenance of health and the prevention, alleviation, or cure of disease."\nFood acts as medicine--to maintain, prevent, and treat disease.\nWhat does food do in our bodies?\nThe nutrients in food enable the cells in our bodies to perform their necessary functions. This quote from a popular textbook describes how the nutrients in food are essential for our physical functioning.\n"Nutrients are the nourishing substances in food that are essential for the growth, development and maintenance of body functions. Essential meaning that if a nutrient is not present, aspects of function and therefore human health decline. When nutrient intake does not regularly meet the nutrient needs dictated by the cell activity, the metabolic processes slow down or even stop."\n- Perspectives in Nutrition, Wardlow and Insel\xa0Get examples of food as information\nIn other words, nutrients give our bodies instructions about how to function. In this sense, food can be seen as a source of "information" for the body.\nThinking about food in this way gives us a view of nutrition that goes beyond calories or grams, good foods or bad foods. This view leads us to focus on foods we should include rather than foods to exclude.\nInstead of viewing food as the enemy, we look to food as a way to create health and reduce disease by helping the body maintain function.\nWhat are some of the issues with our diet?\nOur Standard American Diet (SAD) is not contributing to our health. \xa0Learn about some of the issues.\nProcessing removes nutrients\nOur supermarkets are full of convenient packaged foods that appeal to our taste buds, but compromise our nutrition. Because most of these foods\' natural nutrients are removed in the refining process, we need to get them elsewhere.\nProcessed foods have additives\nOur Standard American Diet relies heavily on processed foods that include artificial color, additives, flavorings, and chemically-altered fats and sweeteners. These additives and chemically altered substances\xa0may be giving our bodies the wrong signals, instead of the information they need to function properly.\nEven "natural" foods have fewer nutrients\nOur food is not the same as it was 20 years ago. Nutrients in the soil have been depleted, so food grown in that soil has fewer nutrients. Chemicals are increasingly used in raising both plants and animals, particularly on huge industrial farms that specialize in a few products.\nWe are eating less variety of foods\nIronically, while 17,000 new products are introduced each year, two-thirds of our calories come from just four foods: corn, soy, wheat, and rice.\nWe eat for convenience, not pleasure\nWe tend to eat for convenience and speed, not health and pleasure. Our fast foods also remove us from the pleasures of creating and savoring a wonderful meal, and our fast pace often prevents us from connecting over a good, slow meal.\n1 of 62 of 63 of 64 of 65 of 66 of 6\nWhat is the connection between food and disease?\nAs a society we are facing significant health problems.\nThe United States ranks ninth in life expectancy among nations in the developed world.\nWe have a workforce plagued with absenteeism and reduced productivity because of chronic health problems, including depression.\n78 percent of healthcare expenditures are for the treatment of chronic disease.\nMany researchers now believe that these problems are partly related to diet. While they used to believe that diseases-such as type II diabetes, obesity, heart disease, stroke, and certain cancers - were caused by a single gene mutation, they are now generally attributing these conditions to a network of biological dysfunction. And the food we eat is an important factor in that dysfunction, in part because our diets lack the necessary balance of nutrients (Proceedings of the Nutrition Society, 2004).Learn about specific nutrients you need and how to get them\nTo prevent the onset of these diseases, we need to know how multiple nutrients in a diet interact and affect the human body\'s functions, according to the Nutrition Society, Europe\'s largest nutritional organization.\xa0Functional Medicine is a dynamic approach to assessing, preventing, and treating complex and chronic diseases using\xa0nutrition. \xa0This area of healthcare also conducts research on the role that nutrition plays in health.\nThe Functional Medicine Perspective\nOne component of Functional Medicine focuses on how diet impacts health and function. When Functional Medicine practitioners examine the role of nutrition in chronic disease, they look at multiple systems, such as the digestive system, the immune system, and the detoxification system, because of the interconnections between those systems. For instance, because 80% of the immune system is contained in the gastrointestinal system, a person\'s issues with immunity could be related to faulty digestion.\nFunctional Medicine maintains that chronic disease is almost always preceded by a period of declining health in one or more of the body\'s systems. Thus, these practitioners seek to identify early the symptoms that indicate underlying dysfunction, possibly leading to disease.\nOne of the ways Functional Medicine seeks to address declining health is to provide the foods and nutrients needed to restore function. This is a cost effective, non-invasive intervention that aims to stop the progression into disease.\nExample of Cardiovascular Disease\nWhen taking a nutritional approach to health and disease, it is important to understand that one disease might have multiple causes, and one underlying dysfunction might cause multiple diseases. Cardiovascular disease may be among the clearest examples of this concept.\nResearchers have shown that the development of heart disease can be triggered by multiple factors. These factors include insulin resistance, elevated homocysteine, oxidative stress, elevated cholesterol, hypertension, heavy metal toxicity, stress, and inflammation. Each of these factors can be influenced by nutrition and each, in turn, impact our nutritional needs. This applies both to the prevention and treatment of these factors (Textbook of Functional Medicine).\nFor example, a 2007 study shows the importance of optimal mineral balance and how a deficiency in mineral balance can contribute to the development of congestive heart failure (Cardiovascular & Hematological Agents in Medicinal Chemistry, 2007).\nLynn sees huge health benefits with new approach to food\nAt her first visit to a nutritionist, Lynn (53), just had one goal: "I need to get healthy!" Her cholesterol was elevated (including triglycerides), and she had taken Lipitor for five years. Her blood pressure had been elevated in the past. She had acid reflux and had been on Zantac for 15 years. Find out what happened.\nMore\nLynn works with nutritionist and sees huge health benefits\nAt her first visit to a nutritionist, Lynn (53), just had one goal: "I need to get healthy!" Her cholesterol was elevated (including triglycerides), and she had taken Lipitor for five years. Her blood pressure had been elevated in the past. She had acid reflux and had been on Zantac for 15 years.\nShe slept poorly and experienced sleep apnea and extreme fatigue. She was taking hormone replacement therapy for hormonal headaches that had plagued her for years. She had experienced swollen, painful joints for many years, which had developed into osteoarthritis. Her bowels tended toward constipation, and she craved bread and sweets.\nThe nutritionist noted her systemic inflammation, water retention, swelling, and constipation and suspected a food sensitivity. She suggested that Lynn eliminate corn, dairy, and wheat from her diet; keep track of her body\'s reaction to the changes; and then gradually introduce these foods one at a time.\nWhen Lynn returned four weeks later, she had determined through the elimination diet that she had a corn sensitivity. Since eliminating corn, she reported feeling much better, and the pain in her back and legs had diminished. Her constipation was relieved and much of the swelling and fluid retention also improved. Lynn reported that "I lost only five pounds, but I feel smaller."\nReturning at eight weeks, Lynn reported that the, "changes have been easy." She had lost 20 pounds and her energy was much improved: "I wake up ready for the day." She was walking a mile and a half each day and her cravings for sugar had also diminished, much to her delight. She reported feeling more in control of her eating.\nAt 12 weeks, Lynn said the changes were becoming habit. "I feel so much better." Her energy continued to improve; she had lost a total of 27 pounds, and she experienced less pain.\nEmbedded video for How Does Food Impact Health? > Components > Items\nLearn more with Wellbeing U\nIn Wellbeing U, our newest free online learning experience, you\'ll learn about thriving in life and at work, making changes that stick, wellbeing in the workplace, and how mindfulness can make a difference. Participate and be entered in a drawing to win a Fitbit.\nWellbeing U\nExpert Contributor:\nCarolyn Denton, LN\nReviewed by:\nKaren Lawson, MD\nLinda Armstrong, RD, LD, MBA\nReferences\nChadwick, R. (2004). Nutrigenomics, individualism and public health. Proceedings of the Nutrition Society, 63(1), 161-6.\nJones, D.S. (editor) (2006). Textbook of Functional Medicine. Gig Harbor, Washington: Institute for Functional Medicine.\nNewman, K.P. et al. (2007). The importance of lost minerals in heart failure. Cardiovascular & Hematological Agents in Medicinal Chemistry, 5(4), 295-299.\nPollan, M. (2008). In Defense of Food. New York: Penguin Press.\nTaubes, G. (2007). Do We Really Know What Makes Us Healthy? New York Times Magazine, Sept. 16., 52.\nTaubes, G. (2007). Good Calories, Bad Calories. Imagery\nMore info on this topic\nGuided Imagery Home\nHow to use guided imagery\nEvidence for guided imagery\nSources for guided imagery\nGuided imagery uses the power of our own imaginations to foster healing of the mind, body, and spirit and\xa0enhance our functioning or performance. A guided imagery recording or session uses gentle phrases and words that evoke sensations that help us heal.\nGuided imagery works because our bodies do not discern whether an image is real or imagined. When we bring an image to mind, the same parts of the brain light up as if the actual event was happening. So, if we imagine a relaxing image, our bodies relax. Moreover, in a state of relaxed focus (which guided imagery promotes), we are more sensitive to imagery, which makes us capable of more intense healing, growth, learning, and change.\nAlmost anyone can benefit from guided imagery. In most cases, you can practice on your own. You don't even need to believe in guided imagery before starting to experience benefits. Guided imagery can be a powerful way for you to positively influence your emotions and thoughts.\nHow can guided imagery help me?\nAlleviating:\nAnxiety\nStress\nPain\nInsomnia\nCoping with:\nCancer\nMigraine headaches\nIrritable bowel syndrome\nHypertension\nAnxiety\nDepression\nFibromyalgia\nPTSD\nAsthma\nSurgery\nPain\nReaching goals:\nLose weight\nQuit smoking\nPromote healing (wounds, surgery)\nManage chronic pain\nPrepare for public speaking\nPrepare for an athletic event\nSign up for our newsletter\nsign up\nHome\nAbout\nOur Experts\nArticles\nGlossary\nContact Us\nThis site was created by the University of Minnesota's\nDisclaimer\nThis site complies with the HONCode standard for trustworthy health information:\nFor Students, Faculty, and Staff\nOne Stop\nMy U\n© 2016 Regents of the University of Minnesota.
