Cardio WorkoutsFitness - NutritionThere is so much talk about the need to have good cardiovascular fitness to maintain good health these dayshttps://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/cardiovascular-fitness.phphttps://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/cardiovascular-fitness.phpTue, 10 Feb 2009 11:47:17 EDTSat, 26 Mar 2016 18:03:32 EDTDisabled WorldBowflex Fitness and Exercise MachinesFitness - NutritionA Bowflex exercise and fitness machine helps improve muscle flexibility by using power rods attached to pulleys to give you your workouthttps://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/bowflex-machine.phphttps://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/bowflex-machine.phpFri, 06 Feb 2009 12:08:22 EDTTue, 26 Feb 2019 23:19:35 EDTDisabled World", 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/', 'content': 'Disability Fitness : Nutrition and Health : Disabled WorldScreen Readers Skip to ContentHOME ☰ Menu Disability News Tweet Facebook BufferSubtopicsFitness - Nutrition ListDisability Loans & GrantsDisability Fitness : Nutrition and HealthDisabled World (disabled-world.com)Revised/Updated: Friday, 27th March 2020Synopsis and Key Points:Information on achieving and maintaining health, fitness level, and nutrition intake for people with disabilities in order to maintain strength, muscle mass, and healthy cardiovascular system.The escalating rate of workplace disabilities is causing businesses and consumers alike to revisit how they handle stress and health issues.When we keep our bodies active through a consistent exercise program, we are adding to our body\'s ability to metabolize food and keep weight down.Main DocumentIn the age which we live there is an unprecedented focus on getting and staying healthy. As more and more research points to the effect of fitness and nutrition on our overall health, the findings become more difficult to ignore. There is no doubt that the food that we eat and the physical activity that we perform significantly impact our weight and our body\'s overall health and longevity.Nutrition is defined as the intake of food, considered in relation to the body\'s dietary needs.\nGood Nutrition - An adequate, well balanced diet combined with regular physical activity, is a cornerstone of good health.\nPoor Nutrition - Can lead to reduced immunity, increased susceptibility to disease, impaired physical and mental development, and reduced productivity.\nThe diet of an organism is what it eats, which is largely determined by the availability, processing and palatability of foods. A healthy diet includes preparation of food and storage methods that preserve nutrients from oxidation, heat or leaching, and that reduce risk of food-born illnesses.\nDiet and nutrition refers to the intake of food and nourishment for the growth and maintenance of the body. Dietitians or nutritionists consider a diet as a balanced meal that contains appropriate portions of all nutrients.\nA good diet helps a person to maintain good health.\nFitness is the overall well being of the human body.\nDiet and nutrition are therefore an important part of fitness.\nThe escalating rate of workplace disabilities is causing businesses and consumers alike to revisit how they handle stress and health issues.\nHigh stress, lack of exercise and other factors exacerbated by an aging U.S. workforce are contributing to an increase in the numbers of individuals receiving long-term disability payments each year, according to a new study from the Council for Disability Awareness.\nFitness and Nutrition Equal Good Health\nWhen we keep our bodies active through a consistent exercise program, we are adding to our body\'s ability to metabolize food and keep weight down. Further, good fitness means strong and limber muscles and a strong cardiovascular system. Exercise also lowers blood pressure and reduces stress levels.\nA wide variety of colorful nutritious food on display table - Photo by Dan Gold on Unsplash\nWhen you look at fitness and nutrition and the consequences of ignoring their importance, it is not difficult to see how large a role they play in our health. First and foremost, it is important to understand how powerfully diet can affect us. Natural, whole foods - such as fresh vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and lean proteins - give our bodies the vitamins that it needs to function effectively. We have energy when we eat right. And when we have energy we burn fat. Eating properly allows us to maintain a healthy weight and keep undue stress off of our heart; it also allows us to keep our blood pressure and cholesterol levels in the healthy range. Most importantly, good nutrition keeps our bodies stocked with antioxidants that fight off a range of illnesses including cancer.\nRegular exercise is one of the requirements necessary to address health and fitness issues. The types of exercises that will improve and strengthen the heart muscles are highly recommended.\nIf you spend long hours in a wheelchair you know it can lead to uneasiness and be very uncomfortable, which is true for anyone who is disabled. Keeping the body moving as much as possible in your wheelchair should be a regular part of your daily fitness program. This should be a priority no matter what your disability. Doing regular wheelchair exercise will help you increase your strength, flexibility, improve your mobility, strengthen your heart and lungs, and help you control your weight.\nKeep Body Moving\nBurn your excess fat and calories.\nMental stimulation and exercise can be incorporated to keep you mind sharp and sound.\nChallenge your mind to grow, expand, learn, explore, decipher, and experience.\nMeditation can reduce stress, heart rate, and blood pressure.\nResearchers studied 370 member of a runners club for people aged 50 years and older, and 249 community members who did not belong to the running club. They were between 50 and 72 years of age at the start of the 13-year study. The runners had far lower death rates, which was expected, and far less disability, such as osteoarthritis, which is impressive.\nBasic Nutrition Facts\nAdding Sugar is a Disaster.\nUnprocessed Food is Healthiest.\nThere is no Perfect Diet For Everyone.\nRefined Carbohydrates are Bad For You.\nEating Vegetables Will Improve Your Health.\nIt is Critical to Avoid Vitamin D Deficiency.\nSupplements Can Never Fully Replace Real Foods.\n"Diets" Don\'t Work, a Lifestyle Change is Necessary.\nOmega-3 Fats Are Crucial and Most People Don\'t Get Enough.\nArtificial Trans Fats Are Very Unhealthy and Should be Avoided.\nSubtopics and Associated SubjectsChildhood ObesityCooking TipsDieting and Diet PlansExercisingLongevityMetabolismNutritionVegetarianismRelated Information1 - Appetite Loss After Exercising Explained : Albert Einstein College of Medicine (2018/04/25)2 - Facial Exercises Proven to Help Women Appear Younger : Northwestern University (2018/01/04)3 - Old and New Food Pyramid Information and Pictures : Disabled World (2017/12/20)4 - What Happens When We Starve? Phases of Starvation : Thomas C. Weiss (2016/02/01)5 - Overeating of Health Foods Perceived as Less Filling : Cornell Food & Brand Lab (2015/12/28)6 - Sugar Substitutes: General Information on Sweeteners : Thomas C. Weiss (2015/09/10)7 - Man Drinks 10 Cokes a Day - Then 10 Diet Cokes a Day : George Prior (2015/04/03)Important:• Disabled World uses cookies to help provide and enhance our services to you and tailor some content and advertising. Abstract: Information on achieving and maintaining health, fitness level, and nutrition intake for people with disabilities in order to maintain strength, muscle mass, and healthy cardiovascular system. Retrieved 2020-06-30, from https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/ - Reference Category Number: DW#230-17.172.98-5c.Go to Top of PageTerms of ServicePrivacy PolicyCookie PolicyLinking PolicyAdvertising PolicyContact UsReference DeskAbout UsAccessibilitySubmissionsContributors RSS Feed© 2004 - 2020 Disabled World™Your browser does not support JavaScript!', 'urls': {'https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/', 'https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/rss.xml', 'https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/nutrition/fruits-veggies/colored.php', 'https://www.disabled-world.com/disability/finance/'}}, {'url': 'https://www.disabled-world.com/fitness/nutrition/fruits-veggies/colored.php', 'content': 'Color Chart of Healthy Fruits and Vegetables | Disabled WorldScreen Readers Skip to ContentHOME ☰ Menu Disability News Tweet Facebook BufferFitness - NutritionNutritionFruit - VegetablesPublicationsDisability Loans & GrantsColor Chart of Healthy Fruits and VegetablesAuthor: Ian Langtree : Contact: Disabled WorldPublished: 2017-12-01 : (Rev. 2019-11-12)Synopsis and Key Points:List of different color fruits and vegetables that contain unique health components essential to health and wellness.Each different color fruit and vegetable contains unique health components that are essential to our health.The number one excuse for not eating the required five servings of fruits and vegetables each day is they are too expensive.Main DigestThe majority of people know that eating five servings of fruits and vegetables a day is very important. By eating fruits and vegetables of a variety of different colors, one can get the best all-around health benefits.Each different color fruit and vegetable contains unique health components that are essential to our health.\nFruits and vegetables are very important to our health because they are whole foods, created by nature, that are rich in a large amount of nutrients. The processed foods that we so commonly eat, can never compare to the health benefits provided by strawberries or broccoli, which have fiber, vitamins, and enzymes built right in.\nEating plenty of healthy vegetables and fruits helps prevent heart disease and strokes, diverticulitis, control your blood pressure, prevent some types of cancers, and guards against cataract and macular degeneration or vision loss.\nTable 1: Color Chart of Fruit and Vegetable Including Nutrients Specific to Each Color\nColor Chart of Fruit and Vegetable Nutrients\nJump To: Red | Orange/Yellow | Green | Blue/Purple | White\nRed Colored Fruits and Vegetables\nNutrients in Red Fruits and Vegetables\nLycopene, ellagic acid, Quercetin, and Hesperidin, to name a few.\nThese nutrients reduce the risk of prostate cancer, lower blood pressure, reduce tumor growth and LDL cholesterol levels, scavenge harmful free-radicals, and support join tissue in arthritis cases.\nTypes of Red Fruits and Vegetables\nBeets, Blood oranges, Cherries, Cranberries, Guava, Papaya, Pink grapefruit, Pink/Red grapefruit, Pomegranates, Radicchio, Radishes, Raspberries, Red apples, Red bell peppers, Red chili peppers, Red grapes, Red onions, Red pears, Red peppers, Red potatoes, Rhubarb, Strawberries, Tomatoes, and Watermelon.\nOrange and Yellow Fruit and Vegetables\nNutrients in Orange and Yellow Fruit and Vegetables\nBeta-carotene, zeaxanthin, flavonoids, lycopene, potassium, and vitamin C.\nThese nutrients reduce age-related macula degeneration and the risk of prostate cancer, lower LDL cholesterol and blood pressure, promote collagen formation and healthy joints, fight harmful free radicals, encourage alkaline balance, and work with magnesium and calcium to build healthy bones.\nTypes of Yellow and Orange Fruits and Vegetables\nApricots, Butternut squash, Cantaloupe, Cape Gooseberries, Carrots, Golden kiwifruit, Grapefruit, Lemon, Mangoes, Nectarines, Oranges, Papayas, Peaches, Persimmons, Pineapples, Pumpkin, Rutabagas, Sweet corn, Sweet potatoes, Tangerines, Yellow apples, Yellow beets, Yellow figs, Yellow pears, Yellow peppers, Yellow potatoes, Yellow summer squash, Yellow tomatoes, Yellow watermelon, and Yellow winter squash.\nGreen Vegetables and Fruit\nNutrients in Green Vegetables and Fruit\nChlorophyll, fiber, lutein, zeaxanthin, calcium, folate, vitamin C, calcium, and Beta-carotene.\nThe nutrients found in these vegetables reduce cancer risks, lower blood pressure and LDL cholesterol levels, normalize digestion time, support retinal health and vision, fight harmful free-radicals, and boost immune system activity.\nTypes of Green Fruits and Vegetables\nArtichokes, Arugula, Asparagus, Avocados, Broccoflower, Broccoli, Broccoli rabe, Brussel sprouts, Celery, Chayote squash, Chinese cabbage, Cucumbers, Endive, Green apples, Green beans, Green cabbage, Green grapes, Green onion, Green pears, Green peppers, Honeydew, Kiwifruit, Leafy greens, Leeks, Lettuce, Limes, Okra, Peas, Snow Peas, Spinach, Sugar snap peas, Watercress, and Zucchini.\nBlue and Purple Fruits and Vegetables\nNutrients in Blue and Purple Fruits and Vegetables\nLutein, zeaxanthin, resveratrol, vitamin C, fiber, flavonoids, ellagic acid, and quercetin.\nSimilar to the previous nutrients, these nutrients support retinal health, lower LDL cholesterol, boost immune system activity, support healthy digestion, improve calcium and other mineral absorption, fight inflammation, reduce tumor growth, act as an anticarcinogens in the digestive tract, and limit the activity of cancer cells.\nTypes of Blue and Purple Fruits and Vegetables\nBlack currants, Black salsify, Blackberries, Blueberries, Dried plums, Eggplant, Elderberries, Grapes, Plums, Pomegranates, Prunes, Purple Belgian endive, Purple Potatoes, Purple asparagus, Purple cabbage, Purple carrots, Purple figs, Purple grapes, Purple peppers, and Raisins.\nWhite Colored Fruits and Vegetables\nNutrients in White fruits and Vegetables\nBeta-glucans, EGCG, SDG, and lignans that provide powerful immune boosting activity. These nutrients also activate natural killer B and T cells, reduce the risk of colon, breast, and prostate cancers, and balance hormone levels, reducing the risk of hormone-related cancers.\nTypes of White Fruits and Vegetables\nBananas, Brown pears, Cauliflower, Dates, Garlic, Ginger, Jerusalem artickoke, Jicama, Kohlrabi, Mushrooms, Onions, Parsnips, Potatoes, Shallots, Turnips, White Corn, White nectarines, and White peaches.\nAccording to the food pyramid potatoes are not counted as a vegetable, as they are consist mostly of starch and should be consumed sparingly.\nWhat are Nutrients\nThe nutrients found in fruits and vegetables have a significant impact on our health. The phrase "eating a rainbow" of fruits and vegetables is a simple way of remembering to get as much color variety in your diet as possible, so that you can maximize your intake of a broad range of nutrients. The colors of fruits and vegetables are a small clue as to what vitamins and nutrients are included. By getting a variety of different colored fruits and vegetables, you are guaranteed a diverse amount of essential vitamins and minerals.\nTable 2: Color Classifications and Health Benefits\nColorsFruits & VegetablesPhytochemicalsVitamins & MineralsHealth BenefitsReferences\nGreen\nFruits:\nGreen Grapes, Limes, Green Pears, Kiwi, Chayote, Honeydew, Avocado, Green ApplesVegetables:\nAsparagus, Broccoli, Brussels Sprouts, Celery, Greens, Collard Greens, Muster Greens, Turnip Greens, Spinach, Green Beans, Green Peppers, Cabbage, Zucchini, Packaged Salad Bags, Lettuce, Okra, Cucumbers\nLutein Glucosinolates Folate Isothiocyanates Vitamin K folic acid potassium chlorophyll Vitamin C\nPrevent macular degeneration, boost immune system, maintain healthy bones and teeth.\n(Heber 2004, Garden-Robinson 2009, Guitart, Pickering, and Byrne 2014, FNS 2016)\nRed\nFruits:\nCherries, Strawberries, Grapefruit, Watermelon, Blueberries, Plums, Red Grapes, Black Grapes, Red ApplesVegetables:\nBeets, Radish, Tomatoes, Red Peppers, Red Onions\nLycopene Anthocyanins Calcium Vitamin D Flavonoids Resveratrol Vitamin C Folates\nReduce tumor growth and cancer and stroke risk, Promotes memory function, healthy aging, heart, and prostate health.\n(Heber 2004, Garden-Robinson 2009, Joseph, Nadeau, and Underwood 2002, Brown 2016, FNS 2016)\nBlue\nPurple\nYellow\nFruits:\nApricots, Cantaloupe, Pineapple, Yellow Apples, Oranges, Tangerines, Peaches, Mango, Nectarines, LemonsVegetables:\nCarrots, Corn, Pumpkin, Yams, Squash, Yellow Peppers\nAlpha-Carotene Beta-Carotene Vitamin A Vitamin C folate\nPromote vision and immune system; reduce cancer risk, and heart disease.\n(PbhFoundation 2016b, Joseph, Nadeau, and Underwood 2002, Brown 2016, FNS 2016)\nOrange\nWhite\nFruits:\nBananas, Coconuts, Bosc PearsVegetables:\nPlantain, Cauliflower, White Onions, Mushrooms, Turnips, Russet Potatoes, Idaho Potatoes, Jicama, Yuca\nAllyl Sulfides Allicin Potassium\nPrevent certain cancers; maintain cholesterol levels.\n(Langtree 2005, Heber 2004, FNS 2016)\nWhat is Quercetin?\nFound in apples, onions and other citrus fruits, not only prevents LDL cholesterol oxidation, but also helps the body cope with allergens and other lung and breathing problems.\nWhat is Ellagic Acid?\nMainly found in raspberries, strawberries, pomegranates, and walnuts, has been proven in many clinical studies to act as an antioxidant and anticarcinogens in the gastrointestinal tract. This nutrient also has been proven to have an anti- proliferative effect on cancer cells, because it decreases their ATP production.\nThe best-known of the carotenoids, beta-carotene, is converted into vitamin A upon entering the liver. Although being known for its positive effects on eyesight, it has also been proven to decrease cholesterol levels in the liver.\nClinical studies have proven that lycopene, mainly found in tomatoes, may decrease the risk of prostate cancer, as well as protect against heart disease. Lutein, which is found in blueberries and members of the squash family, is important for healthy eyes. However, it does support your heart too, helping to prevent against coronary artery disease.\nAlong with the above stated nutrients, there are even more nutrients found in fruits and vegetables that provide a great deal of support to our body. Almost everyone has heard of vitamin C, which keeps our immune system strong; speeds wound healing, and promote strong muscles and joints. This nutrient is scattered throughout the spectrum of fruits, but commonly associated with oranges and other citrus fruits. Potassium, which is the nutrient most Americans are deficient in, does great things for our hearts, and lowers blood pressure.\nAnother good food component many people don\'t get enough of is fiber, found in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.\nWhat are Flavonoids?\nInclude anthocyanins, flavones, isoflavones, proantocyanidins, quercetin and more, are found almost everywhere. They are responsible for the colors in the skins of fruits and vegetables and help to stop the growth of tumor cells and potent antioxidants. They also can reduce inflammation.\nWhat is Beta-glucan?\nFound in mushrooms, stabilizes and balances the body\'s immune system by supporting white blood cells. EGCG is found in tea and has been shown to reduce the risk of colon and breast cancer. It boosts the immune system and encourages T-cell formation, which defends our body against sickness and disease.\nWhat are Bioflavonoids?\nFound in citrus fruits, are considered a companion to vitamin C because they extend the value of it in the body. These nutrients have the capabilities to lower cholesterol levels and support joint collagen in arthritis cases.\nThe number one excuse for not eating the required five servings of fruits and vegetables each day is they are too expensive. However, as compared to the amount of money spent on pre-packaged, processed, and fast foods, most fruits and vegetables (with the exception of those that are not in season) are not all that expensive.\nBecause frozen fruits and vegetables retain the majority of their nutritional value, they can be an excellent alternative when certain foods are out of season.\nSomeone who is not able to eat five servings of fruits and vegetables each day can also drink fruit and vegetable drinks in their place. Although this shouldn\'t become a habit, fruit and vegetable drink mixes can be an excellent substitute when you\'re rushed or traveling.\nThe need for fruits and vegetables in our diet is growing rapidly with the type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and high cholesterol, hypertension that result from the "Typical American Diet" of fatty meats, processed sugars, and refined grains!\nFurther Information\nList of fruits and vegetables you can freeze\nList of healthy food you should be eating\nEat right with color - National Nutrition Month\nGrapefruit and medications don\'t mix\nPrintable Fruit and Vegetable Color Chart\n(Right click the chart below and select print.)\nPrintable fruit and vegetable color chart showing phytochemicals, vitamins and minerals, and the health benefits of each color.Related Documents1 - How Do I Possibly Eat All Those Fruits and Vegetables? : Disabled World (2017/12/10)2 - Study Finds Lutein May Counter Cognitive Aging : University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2017/07/25)3 - Color Chart of Healthy Fruits and Vegetables : Ian Langtree (2017/12/01)4 - Mangosteen a Natural Pain Relief for Fibromyalgia : Disabled World (2010/11/03)5 - Benefits of Cucumber for Healthy Skin and Eyes : Disabled World (2018/03/13)6 - How to Have a Healthy Face Skin Color : University of Nottingham (2011/01/11)7 - Shortfalls in Carotenoid Intake May Impact Women\'s Health : Weber Shandwick Worldwide (2010/10/05)Important:• Disabled World uses cookies to help provide and enhance our services to you and tailor some content and advertising. Includes disability loans, grants, home ownership and mortgage guides, plus information on obtaining funds for accessible vehicles.Financial aid programs cover lending institutions for low income people in major countries including Australia, Canada, New Zealand, UK, and U.S.If you enter into a valid loan agreement, the value of the cash or item you receive is not income and does not reduce your Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefit.Main DocumentIn these troubled times of COVID-19 we hope our list of loans and grants may be of some assistance to you. As we research legitimate specific Coronavirus stimulus payments, and low to no interest loans, both personal and business, we will either list them below or link to a new dedicated page from here.\nDue to the limited information currently available online in regards to reputable sources of disability loans and grants for the disabled, Disabled World has compiled an online resource of financial assistance programs available including grants for low income families as well as singles, the elderly, disabled students, and people with disabilities.Please Note: Disabled World does NOT provide loans, grants, or scholarships ourselves, but we do list helpful information and resources that may assist you to better source and navigate the online maze in order to obtain monetary assistance. The listed financial aid programs cover lending institutions for low income people in major world countries including Australia, Canada, New Zealand, UK, and the U.S.\nDefining Loans and Grants\nLoan DefinitionIn finance, a loan is a debt provided by one entity (organization or individual) to another entity at an interest rate, and evidenced by a note which specifies, among other things, principal amount, interest rate, and date of repayment. A loan entails reallocation of the subject asset(s) for a period of time, between the lender and the borrower. Grant DefinitionNon-repayable funds or products disbursed by one party (grant makers), often a government department, corporation, foundation or trust, to a recipient, often a nonprofit entity, educational institution, business or an individual. In order to receive a grant, some form of Grant Writing often referred to as either a proposal or an application is required.\nHaving good credit can help you in a surprising number of ways. A good credit history can result in getting that dream job, lower interest rates on car loans and house mortgages, and aquire better rates on your insurance policies, according to the Insurance Information Institute.\nHome and Housing Finance Information and Calculators\nFirst Home Owners Guide to Mortgages\nHome Budget Calculator for Household Finances\nGuide to Home Buying for People with Disability\nOnline Loan Calculator\nDisability Housing and Home Loans\nSteps to Get Out of Debt\nCrowdfunding Legal Expenses\nHome Purchase or Rent: Pros and Cons Comparison\nIs Buying a House Cheaper Than Renting a Home?\nHome Improvement Loan and Grant Programs (U.S. Only)\nThe purpose of these loans and grants is to enable low-income homeowners to improve the safety and habitability of their homes. These home improvement programs can be implemented at the local, state, or federal levels and provide funding for low-income families to repair their houses, make home improvements, and/or remove health and safety hazards. These programs can be part of a broader home or housing improvement initiative or focused on specific issues such as heating and insulation, lead, or mold.\nHUD Approved Lenders\nFixing Up Your Home and How to Finance It\nHUD\'s Rehabilitation and Repair Loan\nHUD\'s Property Improvement Loan\nHome Improvement Loans for Native Americans\nRural Home Improvement and Repair Loans/Grants\nSingle Family Housing Repair Loans and Grants\nHelp with Home Repairs and House Modifications\nWeatherization Assistance Program\nHelp with Home Energy Bill (U.S.):\nThe Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) may be able to help with:\nAssistance to pay your heating or cooling bills\nEmergency services in cases of energy crisis, such as utility shutoffs\nLow-cost home improvements, known as weatherization, and energy-related minor home repairs that make your home more energy efficient and lower your utility bills.\nNOTE: LIHEAP funds may not be used to pay water and sewer bills.\nU.S. Government Grants, Loans and Unclaimed Money\nListed below are various government loan programs available including grants for disabled people, low income home ownership, home mortgages, down payment loans, car and vehicle modification loans, personal loans, consolidation loans and college or education funding sources.\nGovernment Disability Grants\nFederal Domestic Assistance\nRural Development Loans\nFind the Right Loan for You\nFind and Apply for Government Grants\nBenefits and Gov. Assistance Eligibility\nFederal Housing Admin. (FHA) Loans\nUnclaimed Money from U.S. Gov.\nSmall Business Loans\nEmergency Assistance Funds\nEmergency Solutions Grants Program - ESG funds may be used for five program components: street outreach, emergency shelter, homelessness prevention, rapid re-housing assistance, and HMIS; as well as administrative activities (up to 7.5% of a recipient’s allocation can be used for administrative activities).\nSNAP Grants - Awarded on a first-come, first-served basis, SNAP grants provide funding for the repair and rehabilitation of owner-occupied housing of eligible, special-needs individuals, who can qualify for the grants based on age, disabilities, income and other eligibility standards.\nU.S. Department of Social Security Emergency Loans\nPhoto shows a persons left hand holding a pen and filling in a loan application.\nIn the U.S. The Department of Social Security can grant you an emergency loan of the equivalent to one month\'s benefits entitlement if you appear to qualify for disability through SSI\'s presumptive disability program (presumptive means something that is assumed to happen or assumed to be true). However, U.S. Social Security makes emergency payments to disability applicants only under some very specific circumstances, only those who can prove extreme hardship, e.g. a lack of food or housing, can qualify for the advance payment. This loan is not free money or a grant, it must be paid back from your presumptive disability checks from SSI.\nThe state in which you reside may also have an Interim Assistance (IA) program if you are likely to qualify for SSI. In order to receive a loan through this program you will have to sign what is known as an interim assistance reimbursement agreement, which means you guarantee to pay back this assistance amount from your Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefit payments.\nNOTE: The Interim assistance (IA) program is usually administered by your state\'s public assistance, welfare agency, or department of social services.\nU.S. Supplemental Security Income Expedited Benefit Payments\nIf your claim is for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits for disability or blindness, Social Security may make presumptive disability (PD) or presumptive blindness (PB) payments for up to 6 months while you are waiting for the Disability Determination Services (DDS) to make a final decision. Their decision to grant you PD or PB payments is based on the severity of your condition, the evidence available at the time, and the high likelihood that your claim will be ultimately approved, and is not based on your financial need.\nThe U.S. Department of Social Security MAY be able to make an emergency advance payment to new applicants, who face a financial emergency and are due SSI benefits that are delayed or not received. They will only pay one such advance payment - https://www.ssa.gov/ssi/text-expedite-ussi.htm\nSocial Security Compassionate Allowance Conditions List - Compassionate allowances are a way of quickly identifying diseases and other medical conditions that clearly qualify for Social Security and Supplemental Security Income disability benefits. The compassionate allowances list allows the U.S. Department of Social Security to make speedy decisions for the most obviously disabled individuals. If a claimant has a condition on the Compassionate Allowance list the SSA can approve their disability in as little as 10 days, with limited medical information which proves their diagnosis.\nCan Getting a Loan Affect My SSI Benefit?\nIf you enter into a valid loan agreement, the value of the cash or item you receive is not income and does not reduce your Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefit. However, any funds that you may borrow - which you do not spend in that month - will count toward your SSI resource limit the next month - (https://www.ssa.gov/ssi/spotlights/spot-loans.htm)\nSupplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) (Food Stamps)\nThe Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or, \'SNAP,\' which was called, \'food stamps,\' in the past assists people with low-incomes to purchase food. While it is a program through the federal government, it is run by state and local agencies.\nAnyone may apply for SNAP although a person and others in their household need to meet specific conditions. Everyone who is applying in a household needs to have or apply for a Social Security number and must be either a United States citizen, a U.S. national, or have status as a qualified alien. Further information regarding the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.\nHousing Grants for Disabled Veterans\nVeterans Affairs (VA) provides grants to Service-members and Veterans with certain permanent and total service-connected disabilities to help purchase or construct an adapted home, or modify an existing home to accommodate a disability. Two grant programs exist: the Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant and the Special Housing Adaptation (SHA) grant - www.benefits.va.gov/homeloans/adaptedhousing.asp\nVA Home Loan Versus CFHA Loans - A personal experience and comparison between a CFHA home loan and Veteran Affairs housing loans.\nDisability Scholarships and Grants\nStudents with disabilities are advantaged when it comes to grants and scholarships. Since the IDEA made it illegal to segregate students with a disability, there has been a major push to offer grants for disabled students to pursue their educational goals. Not only are there grants for individual students, but the technological support that enables disabled students to participate in matters as well.\nDisabled Students Allowances provide extra financial help if you have a disability or a specific learning difficulty like dyslexia. They are paid on top of the standard student finance package and don\'t have to be repaid. Full-time, part-time and postgraduate students can apply for Disabled Students\' Allowances.\nRequesting a Grant\nGrant Writing for a Wheelchair Van: Information on how to apply for several grants from foundations, non-profits and organizations that provide money for people with disabilities and combining them for a single purchase such as a wheelchair accessible van or truck.Subtopics and Associated SubjectsDisability InformationRelated Information1 - HALO Loans Help Seniors and Disabled with Home Renovations : Solar and Energy Loan Fund (SELF) (2019/01/09)2 - World\'s Largest Autism Grant Will Transform ASD Research : King\'s College London (2018/06/18)3 - Student Loan Discharge Process for Disabled Veterans Made Easier : U.S. Department of Education (2018/04/17)4 - UTA Grant to Help Minority Students Link Assistive Technology with Disability Studies : University of Texas at Arlington (2018/04/16)5 - CSD Learns Awarded $75,000 Grant from Wells Fargo : Wells Fargo and Company (2017/11/17)6 - Adults with Disabilities Remain Outside Economic Mainstream : National Disability Institute (2017/04/28)7 - Finance Now Available on Mountain Trike All-terrain Products : Mountain Trike Company (2017/03/26)Important:• Disabled World uses cookies to help provide and enhance our services to you and tailor some content and advertising. EDTFri, 13 Mar 2015 08:39:44 EDTDisabled World", 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.ssa.gov/ssi/spotlights/spot-loans.htm', 'content': 'SSI Spotlight on Loans\nSkip to content\nCoronavirus (COVID-19) Updates\nSocial Security SEARCH MENU LANGUAGES SIGN IN/UP\nSPOTLIGHT ON LOANS --\n2020 Edition\nLinks to SSI Spotlights Home / Spotlight on Loans\nWHAT IS A LOAN?A loan is anything you receive from someone that you agree to pay for at a\nlater date.\nYou can make the loan agreement with a lending institution such as a\nbank, or an individual, such as a friend or relative.\nYou can make it orally\nor in writing, but it must be enforceable under State law.\nA loan can be:\ncash;\nfood; or\nshelter items (rent, mortgage, utility bills, etc.).\nHOW DOES A LOAN AFFECT MY SSI BENEFIT?\nIf you enter into a valid loan agreement, the value of the cash or item you receive is not income and does not reduce your Supplemental\nSecurity Income (SSI) benefit.\nHowever,\nany funds that you borrow which you do not spend in that month will count toward your SSI resource limit of $2,000 for an individual (or $3,000 for a couple) the next month.\nIf you lend money to someone else, the money they owe you may be a countable resource and may affect your eligibility for SSI.\nDOES INTEREST ON A\nLOAN COUNT AS INCOME FOR SSI?If you lend money to someone else, and we count the loan agreement as a resource, then we do not count the interest you receive as income.\nTHIS INFORMATION IS GENERAL.FOR MORE INFORMATION, CALL 1–800–772–1213 (TTY 1–800–325–0778),\nVISIT OUR WEBSITE\n(www.ssa.gov) ON THE INTERNET,OR CONTACT YOUR LOCAL SOCIAL SECURITY OFFICE.\nBenefits\nRetirement\nDisability\nMedicare\nSurvivors\nSSI\nResources\nOnline Services\nFAQs\nContact Us\nForms\nGlossary\nPublications\nAgency\nAbout Us\nAccessibility\nFOIA\nGuidance\nOpen Government\nPlain Language\nPrivacy\nConnect with Us\nBlog\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYouTube\nAll Social Media\nRelated Websites\nBenefits.gov\nMyMoney.gov\nRegulations.gov\nUSA.gov\nReport Fraud, Waste or Abuse\nOffice of the Inspector General\nThis website is produced and published at U.S. taxpayer expense.\nProtect Yourself from Social Security Scams\n×\nScammers are pretending to be government employees.\nLearn how to protect yourself and report scams.\nwww.ssa.gov', 'urls': {'http://ssa.gov/ssi/links-to-spotlights.htm'}}, {'url': 'http://ssa.gov/ssi/links-to-spotlights.htm', 'content': 'Links to SSI Spotlights\nSkip to content\nCoronavirus (COVID-19) Updates\nSocial Security SEARCH MENU LANGUAGES SIGN IN/UP\nLinks to SSI Spotlights -- 2020 Edition\nSSI Home Page / Links to SSI Spotlights––2020 Edition\nWhat are theSSI Spotlights?\nThese\nspotlights\ngive you\ndetailed\nlooks at some of the program rules\nfound in the\nbooklet, Understanding Supplemental Security Income (SSI).\nThey are\nhandouts to help you\nwhen you apply for\nand receive SSI benefits.\nGo to the Spotlights!\nWho may use theSSI Spotlights?\nWe\nwant the public to use the\nSSI Spotlights.\nWe encourage advocates to\ngive them out\nto\nclients\nand to any other\npeople or groups\nwho can use them.\nThey provide more details than our general information pamphlets.\nCaution!\nThe information in these\nspotlights is\ngeneral.\nDo not apply the information\nto a specific case.\nYou must contact us for specific case information.\nSpanish Language Versions\nWe provide Spanish language spotlights in HTML format,\nthe format we use for the English versions. To see the Spanish version,\nclick on the "En Español" links shown in the chart below. \xa0 Or, from the\nEnglish version,\nclick on the "En\nEspañol" link shown in the upper left of the page. To get back to the English\nversion , click on the\n"In English" link\nin the\nSpanish version.\nSpanish versions of the spotlights are also available at Puntos Importantes de Seguridad de Ingreso Suplementario (SSI).\nLinks\nPlease click on the link(s) below:\nSupplemental\xa0\xa0Security\xa0\xa0Income\xa0\xa0(SSI)\xa0\xa0Spotlights\nRights and ResponsibilitiesLiving ArrangementsResources\nFinancial Institution AccountsBurial FundsLoans\nTrustsDedicated Accounts for ChildrenDeeming Parental Income and Resources\nReporting Your Earningsto Social Security\nSSI Telephone Wage Reporting System and the SSI Mobile Wage Reporting\nApplication\nImpairment–Related\nWork Expenses\nSpecial SSI Rule for\nBlind People Who WorkIndividual Development Accounts\nPlan to Achieve\nSelf–Support\nProperty You Need\nfor Self–SupportTransfers of ResourcesStudent Earned Income Exclusion\nPayment for Travel to\nMedical Exams or Tests\nGetting SSI Benefits While\nYou Try to Sell\nExcess ResourcesContinued SSI Benefits for\nPersons Who are\nTemporarily Institutionalized\nSpecial SSI Rules for\nChildren of Military Personnel\nLiving Overseas\nSSI Benefits for Disabled Youth in Foster Care\nPrerelease Procedure\nSSI Benefits for AliensContinued Medicaid\nEligibility for\nPeople Who Work:\nSection 1619(b)Interpreter Services\nIncome From The Arts\nHomelessness\nWindfall Offset\nOne-Third Reduction Provision\nAchieving a Better Life Experience (ABLE) Accounts\nBenefits\nRetirement\nDisability\nMedicare\nSurvivors\nSSI\nResources\nOnline Services\nFAQs\nContact Us\nForms\nGlossary\nPublications\nAgency\nAbout Us\nAccessibility\nFOIA\nGuidance\nOpen Government\nPlain Language\nPrivacy\nConnect with Us\nBlog\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYouTube\nAll Social Media\nRelated Websites\nBenefits.gov\nMyMoney.gov\nRegulations.gov\nUSA.gov\nReport Fraud, Waste or Abuse\nOffice of the Inspector General\nThis website is produced and published at U.S. taxpayer expense.\nProtect Yourself from Social Security Scams\n×\nScammers are pretending to be government employees.\nLearn how to protect yourself and report scams.\nwww.ssa.gov', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.ssa.gov/ssi/text-expedite-ussi.htm', 'content': 'Understanding SSI - Expedited Payments\nSkip to content\nCoronavirus (COVID-19) Updates\nSocial Security SEARCH MENU LANGUAGES SIGN IN/UP\nUnderstanding Supplemental Security Income Expedited Payments -- 2020 Edition\nUnderstanding SSI Home Page / Understanding Supplemental Security Income Expedited Payments\nEXPEDITED PAYMENTS\nWe can start payments more quickly than usual in four different types of situations:\npresumptive disability (PD) or presumptive blindness (PB) payment;\nemergency advance payment;\nimmediate payment; and\nexpedited reinstatement cases.\nPRESUMPTIVE DISABILITY OR BLINDNESS PAYMENTS\nIf\nyour claim is for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits for disability or\nblindness, we may make presumptive disability (PD) or presumptive blindness (PB)\npayments for up to 6 months while you are waiting for the Disability Determination Services (DDS) to make a final decision. Our\ndecision to grant PD or PB payments is based on the severity of your condition, the evidence\navailable at the time, and the high likelihood that your claim will be\nultimately approved, and is not based on your financial need.\nWe will base the amount of these payments on your countable income.\nSee our chapter on SSI INCOME for an explanation of countable income.\nYou may be eligible to receive SSI benefits right away on the basis of a PD or PB determination if you have one or more of the following medical conditions:\namputation of a leg at the hip;\nallegation of total deafness; that is, no sound perception in either ear;\nallegation of total blindness; that is, no light perception in either eye;\nallegation of bed confinement or immobility without a wheelchair, walker, or crutches, due to a longstanding condition excluding recent accident and recent surgery;\nallegation of stroke (cerebral vascular accident) more than three months in the past and continued marked difficulty in walking or using a hand or arm;\nallegation of cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, or muscular atrophy and marked difficulty in walking (for example the use of braces), speaking, or coordination of the hands or arms;\nallegation of Down syndrome;\nallegation of intellectual disability\nor another neurodevelopmental impairment (for example, autism spectrum\ndisorder) with complete inability to independently perform basic self-care\nactivities (such as toileting, eating, dressing, or bathing) made by another person\nfiling on behalf of a claimant who is at least 4 years of age;\na\nchild has not attained his or her first birthday and the birth certificate or\nother medical evidence shows a weight below 1,200 grams (2 pounds, 10 ounces)\nat birth:\na child has not attained his or her first birthday and available medical evidence shows a gestational age (GA) at birth with these corresponding birth-weights:\n- GA: 37-40 weeks; weight at birth:\n2000 grams (4 pounds, 6 ounces) or less;\n- GA: 36 weeks; weight at birth: 1875 grams (4 pounds, 2 ounces) or less;\n- GA: 35 weeks; weight at birth: 1700 grams (3 pounds, 12 ounces) or less;\n- GA: 34 weeks; weight at birth: 1500 grams (3 pounds, 5 ounces) or less; or\n- GA: 33 weeks; weight at birth: at least 1200 grams, but no more than 1325 grams\n(2 pounds, 15 ounces)\xa0or less;\n- GA:\n32 weeks; weight at birth; at least 1,200 grams (2 pounds, 10 ounces), but less\nthan 1,325 grams (2 pounds, 15 ounces);\nsymptomatic\nhuman immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or acquired immunodeficiency\nsyndrome (AIDS); Form SSA-4814-F5 or SSA-4815-F6 is needed;\na physician confirms by telephone or in a signed statement that an individual has a terminal illness with a life expectancy of six months or less; or a physician or knowledgeable hospice official (for example, hospice coordinator, staff nurse, social worker or medical records custodian) confirms that an individual is receiving hospice services because of a terminal illness;\nallegation of a spinal cord injury\nproducing an inability to ambulate without the use of a walker or bilateral\nhand-held assistive devices for more than two weeks with confirmation of such\nstatus from an acceptable medical source;\nallegation of end-stage renal disease (ESRD)\nrequiring chronic dialysis and the file contains a completed CMS-2728-U3 (End\nStage Renal Disease Medical Evidence Report-Medicare Entitlement and/or Patient\nRegistration); or\nallegation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) known as Lou\xa0Gehrig\'s\xa0disease.\nIf we are not able to make a PD or PB determination, sometimes the DDS will make a PD or PB determination based on one of the medical conditions listed above, or on the basis of another severe condition, if a final approval seems likely.\nWHAT HAPPENS TO PRESUMPTIVE DISABILITY OR BLINDNESS PAYMENTS IF WE LATER DENY YOUR SSI?\nWe do not ask you to repay these PD or PB payments, even if you are later found not to be disabled or blind.\nHowever, if you received an overpayment for other\nreasons, (for example, excess income, SGA, or resources), we may ask you to\nrepay some of the PD or PB payments.\nEMERGENCY ADVANCE PAYMENT\nWe may be able to make an emergency advance payment to new applicants, who face a financial emergency and who are due SSI benefits that are delayed or not received.\nWe can only pay one such advance payment. The maximum emergency advance payment you may receive is the smallest of:\nthe SSI Federal benefit rate (plus any federally administered State supplement);\nthe total amount of the benefits due; or\nthe amount requested for the financial emergency.\nWHO CAN RECEIVE AN EMERGENCY ADVANCE PAYMENT?\nPeople who are due SSI benefits (including PD or PB payments) that are delayed or not received; and\nAre facing a "financial emergency"––which means they need money right away due to a threat to health or safety, such as not enough money for food, clothing, shelter or medical care.\nHOW DO WE RECOVER AN EMERGENCY ADVANCE PAYMENT?\nWe will subtract the emergency advance payment from the payments already due you and pay you the difference.\nIf you are not due past payments, we will subtract the emergency advance payment from your current monthly benefits in up to 6\xa0monthly installments.\nIMMEDIATE PAYMENT\nWe may be able to make an immediate payment to new applicants and those already receiving SSI\nwhose benefits are delayed or not received and who face a financial emergency.\nThe immediate payment cannot be higher than $999.00.\nWHO CAN RECEIVE AN IMMEDIATE PAYMENT?\nPeople who are initially applying for SSI benefits, or already receiving benefits; and\nAre due SSI benefits (including PD or PB payments) that are delayed or not received; and\nAre facing a "financial emergency"––which means they need money right away due to a threat to health or safety, such as not enough money for food, clothing, shelter or medical care.\nHOW DO WE RECOVER AN IMMEDIATE PAYMENT?\nWe will subtract the immediate payment from the first regular payment due to you.\nThe decision to issue an immediate payment is up to us.\nYou do not have formal appeal rights if we decide you are not eligible for any of these payments.\nEXPEDITED REINSTATEMENT (EXR)\nIf your benefits ended because you worked and had earnings, you can request to have your benefits started again without having to complete a new application.\nWe call this process "expedited reinstatement".\nYou can request that your benefits start again if you:\nstopped receiving benefits because of earnings from work;\nare unable to do substantial gainful activity because of an impairment(s) that is the same\nas or related to the impairment(s) that allowed you to get benefits earlier; and\nmake the request within five\xa0years from the month your benefits ended.\nIn order to reinstate your benefits under this provision we need updated medical information for the DDS to make their determination.\nA Social Secuirty representative will assist you with all the necessary forms.\xa0\xa0If we approve your request for expedited reinstatement of your SSI benefits, your provisional (temporary) benefits will begin the month after your request.\nYou may be eligible for Medicaid coverage.\nWe can give you provisional benefits for up to 6\xa0months while we determine whether you can get benefits again.\nThese benefits include Federal payments and Medicaid coverage.\nIf we decide that you cannot get benefits again, we usually will not ask you to repay the provisional benefits.\nBack\xa0\xa0\xa0Top\xa0\xa0Next\nBenefits\nRetirement\nDisability\nMedicare\nSurvivors\nSSI\nResources\nOnline Services\nFAQs\nContact Us\nForms\nGlossary\nPublications\nAgency\nAbout Us\nAccessibility\nFOIA\nGuidance\nOpen Government\nPlain Language\nPrivacy\nConnect with Us\nBlog\nFacebook\nInstagram\nTwitter\nYouTube\nAll Social Media\nRelated Websites\nBenefits.gov\nMyMoney.gov\nRegulations.gov\nUSA.gov\nReport Fraud, Waste or Abuse\nOffice of the Inspector General\nThis website is produced and published at U.S. taxpayer expense.\nProtect Yourself from Social Security Scams\n×\nScammers are pretending to be government employees.\nLearn how to protect yourself and report scams.\nwww.ssa.gov', 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.nhs.uk/live-well', 'content': "Live Well - NHS\nSkip to main content\nMenu\nSearch\nSearch the NHS website\nSearch\nClose search\nMenu\nClose menu\nHome\nHealth A-Z\nLive Well\nCare and support\nHealth news\nServices near you\nHome\nBack to Home\nLive Well\nAdvice, tips and tools to help you make the best choices about your health and wellbeing.\nEat well\nAll you need to know about the major food groups and a healthy, balanced diet\nHealthy weight\nCheck your BMI using our healthy weight calculator and find out if you're a healthy weight\nExercise\nProgrammes, workouts and tips to get you moving and improve your fitness and wellbeing\nSleep and tiredness\nFind out how to sleep well and the common lifestyle factors that are making you tired\nSexual health\nEverything you need to know about sexual health, including contraception, STIs and good sex\nAlcohol support\nFind out the health benefits of reducing your alcohol intake and get tips on cutting down\nQuit smoking\nLearn policies\nCookies\n© Crown copyright", 'urls': set()}, {'url': 'https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/business-and-enterprise/regulation/food-safety/food-information-regulations', 'content': "Food information regulations | Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea\nHomeServices\nServices\nBenefitsBins and recyclingBirths, deaths, marriages and citizenshipBusiness and enterpriseChildren and education\nCommunity and local lifeCouncil TaxCouncil, councillors and democracyEnvironmentGrenfell Response and Recovery\nHealth and Social CareHousingJobsLeisure and cultureLibraries\nLicensingNew residentsParking, transport and streetsPlanning and Building Control\nClose menuPay onlineReport a problemNews\nAccessibilityMyRBKC Sign inMyRBKC Register\nCoronavirus (COVID-19) updates: We're here to help.\nGet the latest information on our response to Coronavirus, Council Service updates and support for residents and local businesses.\nRead more\nHomepage\nBusiness and enterprise\nFood information regulations\nFood information regulations\nThe Food Information Regulations and EU Food Information for Consumer Regulations (EU FIC)The Food Labelling Regulations 1996 have been replaced by the EU Food Information Regulation 1169/2001 (FIR). This legislation came into force on 13 December 2011.The main requirements are detailed in the Food Information Regulations 2014 and this includes an annex covering general and more specific changes to nutrition labelling which are covered in the Food Information for Consumer Regulations (FIC).These new regulations apply to all food businesses supplying food to the public and caterers, including retail premises, manufacturers, restaurants, delicatessens, bakeries, sandwich bars, supermarkets, caterers, take-aways, buffets, and home caterers. There are some exemptions for example private individuals providing food for events such as church, village or school fetes where there is no food business element.Compliance dates1 January 2014 – For the rules on the composition and labelling of minced meat13 December 2014 – For the general labelling rules, and if provided, a nutrition declaration must use the format set out in the EU FIC from this date13 December 2016 – For the rules on the mandatory nutrition declaration needed for most pre-packaged foodsThe essentialsMuch of what is detailed in the current Food Labelling Regulations 1996 remains unchanged.\xa0There is no change in the fundamental principles of providing safe food which is honestly described and not misleading. In addition foods cannot be labelled to state they will prevent, treat or cure a human disease. The following information must be required in English on prepacked food labelling:A true name or description of the foodThe ingredients it contains, in descending weight orderHow it should be handled, stored, cooked or preparedWho manufactured, packed or imported itOrigin information if its absence would misleadAllergenic ingredients identified on the labelSpecific information declaring whether the food is irradiated or contains genetically modified material or aspartame, high caffeine, sweeteners, packaging gases etcNet quantity in grams, kilograms, litres etcAlcoholic strength where there is more than 1.2% alcohol by volumeMain changesAllergensBusinesses will need to provide information if any of the foods/ingredients detailed in the EU Regulations and indicated below are used in the preparation of food they supply. This information can be provided on labels, shelf-edge, menus or verbally if requested by the customer.The 14 ingredients or products thereof causing allergies or intolerances are:Cereals containing gluten (wheat, rye, barley, oats, spelt, kamut), Crustaceans, Molluscs, Eggs, Fish, Peanuts, Soybeans, milk (including lactose), Nuts, Celery, Mustard, Sesame Seeds, Lupin and Sulphur Dioxide and Sulphites (at concentrations of more than 10mg/kg)If the food is non-pre-packed such as in a restaurant or café then the information about allergens can be supplied on the menu, on chalk boards, tickets or provided verbally by an appropriate member of staff as well as in other formats made available to the consumer. It must be clear and conspicuous, not hidden away, easily visible, and legible. If the information is to be provided verbally by a member of staff then it is necessary to make it clear that the information can be obtained by asking a member of staff by means of a notice, menu, ticket or label that can easily be seen by customers.Allergen information must be specific to the food, complete and accurate. This also applies to foods prepacked for direct sale such as from deli counters or sandwich bars.Refusal to give information, inaccurate or incomplete information about allergenic ingredients used in foods sold non-prepacked or pre-packed for direct sale would be a breach of the EU Food Information for Consumers Regulations.Irradiated foodsFoods that are treated with ionising radiation must be labelled with the words ‘irradiated’ or ‘treated with ionising radiation’ as stated in Directive 1999/2/EC. Where an irradiated product is used as an ingredient in another product, the same words must accompany its designation in the list of ingredients.AdditivesFood additives (and enzymes) which are used as processing aids do not generally have to be listed as ingredients.The name of a foodThe name of the food is not required under the European legislation but may be required by UK provisions. Where there is a name laid down by law this must be used. If not, a customary name may be used. If there is no customary name, or it is not used, a descriptive name must be used. The name of a food may consist of a name, a description, or both.Additional changes affecting pre-packed foodAllergen labelling for pre-packed foodAllergens listed in the EU Food Information for Consumers Regulations 1169/2011 must be declared in the ingredients list on prepacked food and emphasised through a different font, style etc. If it is not obvious from the name of the ingredient, there needs to be a clear reference to the name of the allergen next to it. E.g. stock (from fish)’, couscous (wheat)’, ‘tahini (sesame)’, casein (milk), and tofu (soya)Allergen ingredients must not be repeated elsewhere on the labelling, however sign posting to the allergen information within the ingredients list is allowed.\xa0 For example, the use of ‘Contains’: followed by a list of allergens will no longer be permitted. Voluntary statements highlighting the risk of cross contamination with allergens may still be used.Example of a label indicating ingredients and allergens:Ingredients: Figs (35%), barley, flakes, toasted and malted oat flakes (oat flakes, barley malt extract), toasted and malted wheat flakes (wheat, barley malt extract), nuts (8%) (brazil nuts, whole hazelnuts) oat flakes, wheat flakes, sunflower seeds (2%)! allergy advicePlease see ingredients for allergens.May contain other nuts and milkNutritional labellingFrom 13 December 2016 all prepacked food must be labelled with nutrition information which must be in a set prescribed format (commonly referred to as “back of pack” or “traffic light “nutrition labelling). This comprises energy values (in kilojoules (Kj) and kilocalories (kcal)) plus the amounts (in grams (g)) of fat, saturates, carbohydrate, sugars, protein and salt.Previously nutritional information was only required where a claim was made such as ‘low in fat’.Even if you already provide this information you may need to amend your labelling as the legislation requires this information to be provided in a prescribed order and the salt content is now required rather than sodium.There are some exceptions and specific requirements and these are detailed in the Annex of The Food Information Regulations 2014.\nFood Information Regulations 2014\nPDF\n273.32 KB\nDownload\nField of vision requirementsA minimum font size has been set for all mandatory information; the height of the letter ‘x’ in the chosen font must not be less than 1.2mm.\xa0The field of vision requirements no longer include durability. Only the name of the food, net quantity and alcoholic volume need to be able to be read by the consumer from a single view point.Distance selling requirementsAll mandatory information must be provided both before the purchase is concluded (except for durability date) and at delivery and at no additional cost. So if a Food Business Operator (FBO) is making the information available through a telephone helpline then this number must be a free-phone line.Commercial sellingFormerly food supplied between some businesses was exempt from labelling requirements. However, now everyone in the supply chain must ensure mandatory information is available on the food labelling or on documents such as invoices so that those further down the supply chain can meet their obligations.LanguageFood information must be given in English, however, it can also be provided in other languages.Name of the foodWhere there is a name laid down by law this must be used.\xa0If not a customary name may be used.\xa0If there is no customary name, or it is not used, a descriptive name must be used.\xa0The name of a food may consist of a name, a description or both. In the case of some foods, there are compulsory product names that must be used for foods meeting certain composition criteria.The name of food has always needed to include a reference to the physical condition or treatment the food has undergone such as ‘powered’, ‘dried’, ‘smoked’, ‘concentrated’ etc.\xa0This has now been extended to include an indication if the food has been defrosted.The word ‘formed’ must be used when meat or fish products have been made from different pieces of meat and yet have the appearance of a whole piece of meat.Name of the businessThe FBO whose name appears on the labelling is the business responsible for the information on the label.\xa0This must be a FBO in the EU or, where the food is imported into the EU, the importer into the EU.Country of originSome of the origin labelling provisions have yet to be agreed.\xa0These will be subject to the Commission report.The origin or place of provenance of a food must be given if it misleads consumers by its absence.County of origin labelling has now been extended to the meat of pigs, sheep, goats and poultry.\xa0Beef, fish, honey, olive oil, fresh fruit and vegetables already require this.FreezingThe date of first freezing is required on meat and fishery products.Minced meatEuropean compositional standards and additional labelling requirements are required for prepacked minced meat. If you are selling only in the UK different rules apply and a ‘national’ mark must be used.\xa0This was a requirement from 1 January 2014.Animal/vegetable fats and oilsThe source of any animal or vegetable oil or fat ingredient must be provided and displayed in the ingredients list e.g., palm oil, beef fat.\xa0If hydrogenated fats are used a full description must be used such as ‘fully or partly hydrogenated.’What do I need to do?As a Food Business Operator you need to know how the legislation will affect your business and you need to start making plans now so that you comply in time.Detailed food labelling legislation\xa0information can be found on the European Commission website.Further guidance\nFood Information Regulations 2014\nPDF\n273.32 KB\nDownload\nGuide to creating a front of pack nutrition label for pre-packed products sold through retail outlets\nPDF\n1.01 MB\nDownload\nAllergy and Tolerance: guidance to businesses\nTown Hall, Hornton Street, W8 7NX\n© 2020 The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea\nContact us\nTerms of use\nAccessibility\nData Protection\nCookies and your privacy", 'urls': {'http://food.gov.uk/business-industry/guidancenotes/allergy-guide/', 'http://ec.europa.eu/food/safety/labelling_nutrition/labelling_legislation/index_en.htm'}}, {'url': 'http://food.gov.uk/business-industry/guidancenotes/allergy-guide/', 'content': 'Allergen guidance for food businesses | Food Standards Agency\nSkip to main content\nGoogle Tag Manager\nEnglishCymraeg\nOpen mobile navigation\nFood Standards Agency - (Northern Ireland)\nNutrition (Northern Ireland)\nBack\nCheck the label\nThe Eatwell Guide\nFolic acid\nBusiness guidance\nBusiness guidance\nBack\nBusiness guidance\nStarting a food business\nStarting a food business\nBack\nRegistering a food business\nSetting up a food business\nManaging food safety\nFood safety for food delivery\nFood hygiene for your business\nOnline food advice\nBack\nThe UK has left the EU\nCannabidiol (CBD) guidance\nImports and exports\nAllergen labelling\nFarming and animal feed\nMeat and slaughter\nFish and shellfish\nWine\nFrozen food\nChemical
